hymns.title: HYMN I. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: THE men from fire-sticks, with their hands' swift movement, have, in deep thought, engendered glorious Agni, Far-seen, with pointed flame, Lord of the homestead.

p: The Vasus set that Agni in the dwelling, fair to behold, for help from every quarter: Who, in the home forever, must be honoured.

p: Shine thou before us, Agni, well-enkindled, with flame, most Youthful Deva, that never fadeth. To thee come all our offerings offerings.

p: Among all fires these fires have shone most brightly, splendid with light, begirt by noble heroes, Where men of lofty birth sit down together.

p: Victorious Agni, grant us wealth with wisdom, wealth with brave sons, famous and independent, Which not a foe who deals in magic conquers.

p: To whom, the Strong, at morn and eve comes, maid-like, the ladle dropping oil, with its oblation. Wealth-seeking comes to him his own devotion.

p: Burn up all malice with those flames, O Agni, where in old though conquered Jarutha, and drive away in silence pain and sickness.

p: With him who lighteth up thy splendour, Agni, excellent, pure, refulgent, purifier, be present, and with us through these our praises.

p: Agni, the patriarchal men, the mortals who have in many places spread thy lustre. Be gracious to us here for their sake also.

p: Let these men, heroes in the fight with foemen, prevail against all godless arts of 4magic. These who ipprove the noble song I sing thee.

p: Let us not sit in want of men, O Agni, without descendants, heroleu, about thee: But, O House-Friend, in houses full of children.

p: By offering there make our dwelling rich in seed and offspring, increasing still with lineal successors.

p: Guard us, O Agni, guard us from malice of the churlish sinner: Allied with the, may I subdue assailants.

p: May this same fire of mine surpass all others, this fire where offspring, vigorous and firm-handed, Wins, on a thousand paths, what ne’er shall perish.

p: This is that Agni, saviour from the foeman, who guards the kindler of the flame from sorrow: Heroes of noble lineage serve and tend him.

p: This is that Agni, served in many places, whom the rich lord who brings oblation kindles, and round him goes the Sage at offers.

p: Agni. May we with riches in possession bring thee continual ofierings in abundance, Using both means to draw thee to our worship.

p: Agni, bear thou, Eternal, these most welcome oblations to the Deities' assembly: Let them enjoy our very fragrant presents.

p: Give us not up, Agni, to want of heroes, to wretched clothes, to need, to destitution. Yield us not, Holy One, to fiend or hunger; injure us not at home or in the forest.

p: Give strength and power to these my meditations, O Agni, pour blessings on our chiefs and nobles. Grant that both we and the, may share thy bounty. Ye Devas, protect us evermore with blessings.

p: Thou Agni, swift to hear, art fair of aspect: beam forth, O Son of Strength, in full effulgence. Let me not want, with thee, a son forever: let not a manly hero ever fail us.

p: Condemn us not to indigence, O Agni, beside these flaming fires which Devas have kindled; Nor, even after fault, let thy displeasure, thine as a Deva, O Son of Strength, o’ertake us.

p: O Agni, fair of face, the wealthy mortal who to the Immortal offers his oblation. Hath him who wins him treasure. by his Deva.ead, to whom the prince, in need, goes supplicating.

p: Knowing our chief felicity, O Agni, bring hither ample riches to our nobles, Wherewith we may enjoy ourselves, O Victor, with undiminished life and hero children.

p: Give strength and power to these my meditations, O Agni, pour blessings on bur chiefs and nobles. Grant that both we and the, may share thy bounty. Ye Devas, protect us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN II. Apris.
hymns.text:
p: GLADLY accept, this day, our fuel, Agni: send up thy sacred smoke and shine sublimely. Touch the celestial summits with thy columns, and overspread thee with the rays of Surya.

p: With offering to these we men will honour the majesty of holy Narasamsa- To these the pure, most wise, the thought. inspirers, Devas who enjoy both sorts of our oblations.

p: We will extol at offering forever, as me. May do, Agni whom Manu kindled, Your very skilful Asura, meet for worship, envoy between both worlds, the truthful speaker.

p: Bearing the sacred grass, the men who serve him strew it with reverence, on their knees, by Agni. Calling him to the spotted grass, oil-sprinkled, adorn him, ye Adhvaryus, with oblation.

p: With holy thoughts the pious have thrown open Doors fain for chariots in the Devas’ assembly. Like two full mother cows who lick their youngling, like maidens for the gathering, they adorn them.

p: And let the two exalted Heavenly Ladies, Morning and Night, like a cow good at milking, Come, much-invoked, and on our grass be seated ' wealthy, deserving worship, for our welfare.

p: You, Bards and Singers at men's offers, both filled with wisdom, I incline to worship. Send up our offerings when we call upon you, and so among the Devas obtain us treasure.s.

p: May Bharati with all her Sisters, Ila accordant with the Devas, with mortals Agni, Sarasvati with all her kindred Rivers, come to this grass, Three Devas, and seat them.

p: Well pleased with us do thou, O Deva, O Tvastar, give ready issue to our procreant vigour, whence springs the hero, powerful, skilled in action, lover of Devas, adjuster of the press-stones.

p: Send to the Devas the oblation, Lord of Forests, and let the Immolator, Agni, dress it. He as the truer Monk shall offer worship, for the Deva'sgenerations well he knoweth.

p: Come thou to us, O Agni, duly kindled, together with the potent Devas and Indra. On this our grass sit Aditi, happy Mother, and let our Hail! delight the Devas Immortal.

hymns.title: HYMN III. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: ASSOCIATE with fires, make your Deva.Agni envoy at offering, best skilled in worship, Established firm among mankind, the Holy, flame-crowned and fed with oil, the Purifier.

p: Like a steed neighing eager for the pasture, when he hath stepped forth from the great enclosure: Then the wind following blows upon his splendour, and, straight, the path is black which thou hast travelled.

p: From thee a Bull but newly born, O Agni, the kindled everlasting flames rise upward. Aloft to heaven thy ruddy smoke ascendeth: Agni, thou speedest to the Devas as envoy.

p: Thou whose fresh lustre o’er the earth advanceth when greedily with thy jaws thy food thou eatest. Like a host hurried onward comes thy lasso: fierce, with thy tongue thou piercest, as ’twere barley.

p: The men have decked him both at eve and morning, most Youthful Agni, as they tend a courser. They kindle him, a guest within his dwelling: bright shines the splendour of the worshipped Hero.

p: O fair of face, beautiful is thine aspect when, very near at hand, like gold thou gleamestlike Heaven's thundering roar thy might approaches, and like the wondrous Sun thy light thou showest.

p: That we may worship, with your Hail to Agni! with offerings cakes and fat oblations, Guard us, O Agni, with those boundless glories as with a hundred fortresses of iron.

p: Thine are resistless songs for him who offers, and hero-giving hymns wherewith thou savest; With these, O Son of Strength, O Jatavedas, guard us, preserve these princes and the singers.

p: When forth he cometh, like an axe new-sharpened, pure in his form, resplendent in his body, Sprung, sought with eager longing, from his Parents, for the Devas’ worship, Sage and Purifier:

p: Shine this felicity on us, O Agni. May we attain to perfect understanding. All happiness be theirs who sing and praise thee. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN IV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: BRING forth your gifts to his refulgent splendour, your hymn as purest offering to Agni, to him who goes as messenger with knowledge between all songs of men and Devas in heaven.

p: Wise must this Agni be, though young and tender, since he was born, most Youthful. He who with bright teeth seizeth fast the forests, and eats his food, though plenteous, in a moment.

p: Before his presence must we all assemble, this Deva's whom men have seized in his white splendour. This Agni who hath brooked that men should seize him hath shone for man with glow insufferable.

p: Far-seeing hath this Agni been established, deathless mid mortals, wise among the foolish. Here, O victorious Deva, forbear to harm us. May weforever share thy gracious favour.

p: He who hath occupied his Deva-made dwelling, Agni, in wisdom hath surpassed Immortals. A Babe unborn, the plants and trees support him, and the earth beareth him the All-sustainer.

p: Agni is Lord of Amrta. in abundance, Lord of the gift of wealth and hero valour, Victorious Deva, let us not sit about thee like men devoid of strength, beauty, and worship.

p: The foeman's treasure. May be won with labour. May we be masters of our own possessions. Agni, no son is he who springs from others: lengthen not out the pathways of the foolish.

p: Unwelcome for adoption is the stranger, one to be thought of as another's offipring, Though grown familiar by continual presence. May our strong hero come, freshly triumphant.

p: Guard us from him who would assail us, Agni, preserve us O thou Victor, from dishonour. May wealth be ours, desirable, in thousands.

p: Shine this felicity on us, O Agni. May we attain to perfect understanding. All happiness be theirs who sing and praise thee. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN V. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: BRING forth your song of praise to mighty Agni, the speedy messenger of earth and heaven, Vaisvanara, who, with those who wake, hath waxen great in the lap of all the Devas Immortal.

p: Sought in the heavens, on earth is Agni stablished, leader of rivers, Bull of standing waters. Vaisvanara when he hath grown in glory, shines on the tribes of men with light and treasure..

p: For fear of thee forth fled the dark-hued races, scattered abroad, deserting their possessions, when, glowing, O Vaisvanara, for Puru, thou Agni didst light up and rend their castles.

p: Agni Vaisvanara, both Earth and Heaven submit them to thy threefold jurisdiction. Refulgent in thine undecaying lustre thou hast invested both the worlds with splendour.

p: Agni, the tawny horses, loudly neighing our resonant hymns that drop with oil, attend thee; Lord of the tribes, our Charioteer of riches, Ensign of days, Vaisvanara of mornings.

p: In thee, O bright as Mitra, Vasus seated the might of Aduras, for they loved thy spirit. Thou dravest Dasyus from their home, O Agni, and broughtest forth broad light to light the Arya.

p: Born in the loftiest heaven thou in a moment reachest, like wind, the place where Devas inhabit. Thou, favouring thine offspring, roaredst loudly when giving life to creatures, Jatavedas.

p: Send us that strength, Vaisvanara, send it, Agni, that strength, O Jatavedas, full of splendour, Wherewith all-bounteous Deva, thou pourest riches, as fame wide-spreading on the man who offers.

p: Agni, bestow upon our chiefs and nobles that famous power, that wealth which feedeth many. Accordant with the Vasus and the Rudras, Agni, Vaisvanara, give us sure protection.

hymns.title: HYMN VI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: PRAISE of the Asura, high imperial Ruler, the Manly One in whom the folk shall triumph, we laude his deeds.

p: Sage, Sing, Food, Light, they bring him from the mountain, the blessed Sovran of the earth and heaven. I decorate with songs the mighty actions which Agni, did aforetime.

p: The foolish, faithless, rudely-speaking, without belief or offering or worship. Far far sway hath Agni chased those Dasytis, and, in the cast, hath turned the godless wes ward.

p: Him who brought eas ward, manliest with his prowess, the Maids rejoicing in the western darkness, that Agni I extol, the Lord of riches, unyielding tamer of assailing foemen.

p: Him who brake down the walls with deadly weapons, and gave the Mornings to anoble Husband, Young Agni, who with conquering strength subduing the tribes of Nahus made them bring their tribute.

p: In whose protection all men rest by nature, desiring to enjoy his gracious favour- Agni Vaisvanara in his Parents, bosom hath found the choicest seat in earth and heaven.

p: Vaisvanara the Deva, at the sun's setting, hath taken to himself deep-hidden treasure.s: Agni hath taken them from earth and heaven, from the sea under and the sea above us.

hymns.title: HYMN VII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: I SEND forth even your Deva, victorious Agni, like a strong courser, with mine adoration. Herald of offering be he who knoweth he hath reached Devas, himself, with measured motion.

p: By paths that are thine own come hither, Agni, joyous, delighting in the Devas’ alliance, Making the heights of earth roar with thy fury, burning with eager teeth the woods and forests.

p: The grass is strewn;  'the offering advances adored as Monk, Agni is made propitious, invoking both All-boon-bestowing Mothers of whom, most Youthful! thou wast born to help us.

p: Forthwith the men, the best of these for wisdom, have made him leader in the solemn worship. As Lord in homes of men is Agni stablished, the Holy One, the joyous, sweetly speaking.

p: He hath come, chosen bearer, and is seated in man's home, Brahman, Agni, the Supporter. He whom both Heaven and Earth exalt and strengthen whom, Giver of all boons, the Hotar worships.

p: These have passed all in glory, who, the manly, have wrought with skill the hymn of adoration. Who, listening, have advanced the people's welfare, and set their thoughts on this my holy statute.

p: We, the Vasisthas, now implore thee, Agni, O Son of Strength, the Lord of wealth and treasure.. Thou hast brought food to singers and to nobles. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN VIII. Agni
hymns.text:
p: THE King whose face is decked with oil is kindled with homage offered by his faithful servant. The men, the monks adore him with oblations. Agni hath shone forth when the dawn is breaking.

p: Yea, he hath been acknowledged as most mighty, the joyous Monk of men, the youthful Agni. He, spreading o’er the earth, made light around him, and grew among the plants with blackened fellies..

p: How dost thou decorate our hymn, O Agni? What power dost thou exert when thou art lauded? When, Bounteous Deva. May we be lords of riches, winners of precious wealth which non. May conquer?

p: Far famed is this the Bharata's own Agni he shineth like the Sun with lofty splendour. He who hath vanquished Puru in the battle, the heavenly guest hath glowed in full refulgence.

p: Full many oblations are in thee collected: with all thine aspects thou hast waxen gracious. Thou art already famed as praised and lauded, yet still, O nobly born, increase thy body.

p: Be this my song, that winneth countless treasure., engendered with redoubled force for Agni, that, splendid, chasing sickness, subduing demons, i. May delight our friend and bless the singers.

p: We, the Vasisthas, now implore thee, Agni, O Son of Strength, the Lord of wealth and riches. Thou hast brought food to singers and to nobles. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN IX. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: ROUSED from their bosom is the Dawns' beloved, the joyous Monk, most sapient, purifier. He gives a signal both to Devas and mortals, to Devas oblations, riches to the pious.

p: Most wise is he who, forcing doors of Panis, brought the bright Sun to us who feedeth many. The cheerful Monk, men's Friend and home-companion, through still night's darkness he is made apparent.

p: Wise, ne.'er deceived, uncircumscribed, refulgent, our gracious guest, a friend with good attendants. Shines forth with wondrous light before the Mornings; the young plants hath he entered, Child of Waters.

p: Seeking our gatherings, he, your Jatavedas, hath shone adorable through human ages, who gleams refulgent with his lovely lustre: the kine have waked to meet him when enkindled.

p: Go on thy message to the Devas, and fail not, O Agni, with their band who meditate and make offerings. Bring all the Devas that the, may give us riches, Sarasvati, the Maruts, Asvins, Waters.

p: Vasistha, when enkindling thee, O Agni, hath slain jarutha. Give us wealth in plenty. Sing praise in choral song, O Jatavedas. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN X. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: HE hath sent forth, bright, radiant, and refulgent, like the Dawn's Lover, his far-spreading lustre. Pure in his splendour shines the golden Hero: our longing thoughts hath he aroused and wakened.

p: He, like the Sun, hath shone while Morn is breaking, and monks who weave  'the offering sing praises, Agni, the Deva, who knows their generations and visits Devas, most bounteous, rapid envoy.

p: Our songs and holy hymns go forth to Agni, seeking the Deva.and asking him for richeshim fair to see, of heroic nature, mighty, men's messenger who carries their oblations.

p: joined with the Vasus, Agni, bring thou Indra bring hither mighty Rudra with the Rudras, Aditi good to all men with Adityas, Narasamsa All-bounteous, with the Singers.

p: Men eagerly implore at offers Agni, most Youthful Deva, the joyous Herald. For he is Lord and Ruler over riches, and for Devas’ praise and adoration.

hymns.title: HYMN XI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: GREAT art thou, Agni, offering's Herald: not without thee are deathless Devas made joyful. Come hither with all Deities about thee here take thy seat, the first, as Monk, O Agni.

p: Men with oblation evermore entreat thee, the swift, to undertake an envoy's duty. He on whose sacred grass with Devas thou sittest, to him, O Agni, are the days propitious.

p: Three times a day in thee are shown the treasure.s sent for the mortal who presents oblation. Bring the Devas hither like a man, O Agni: be thou our envoy, guarding us from curses.

p: Lord of the lofty offering is Agni, Agni is Lord of every gift presented. The Vasus were contented with his wisdom, so the Devas made him their oblationbearer.

p: O Agni, bring the Devas to taste our presents, with Indra leading, here let them be joyful. Convey this offering to Devas in heaven. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WE with great reverence have approached The Youngest who hath shone forth well-kindled in his dwelling, with wondrous light between wide earth and heaven, well-worshipped, looking forth in all directions.

p: Through his great might o’ercoming all misfortunes, praised in the house is Agni Jatavedas. May he protect us from disgrace and trouble, both us who laud him and our noble patrons.

p: O Agni, thou art Varuna and Mitra: Vasisthas with their holy hymns exalt thee. With thee be most abundant gain of treasure.. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XIII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: BRING song and hymn to Agni, Asura-slayer, enlightener of all and thought-bestower. Like an oblation on the grass, to please him, I bring this to Vaisvanara, hymn-inspirer.

p: Thou with thy flame, O Agni, brightly glowing, hast at thy birth filled full the earth and heaven. TIOU with thy might, Vaisvanara Jatavedas, settest the Devas free frodi the curse that bound them.

p: Agni, when, born thou lookedst on all creatures, like a brisk herdsman moving round his cattle. The path to prayer, Vaisvanara, thou foundest. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XIV Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WITH reverence and with offered gifts serve we the Deva whose flame is bright: Let us bring Jatavedas fuel, and adore Agni when we invoke the Devas.

p: Agni. May we perform thy rites with fuel, and honour thee, O Holy one, with praises: Honour thee, Monk of offering! with butter, thee, Deva.of blessed light! with our oblation.

p: Come, Agni, with the Devas to our invoking, come, pleased, to offerings sanctified with Vasat. May we be his who pays thee, Deva, due honour. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XV. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: OFFER oblations in his mouth, the bounteous Deva's whom we must serve. His who is nearest kin to us:

p: Who for the Fivefold People's take hath seated him in every home Wise, Youthful, Master of the house.

p: On all side. May that Agni guard our household folk and property; May he deliver us from woe.

p: I have begotten this new hymn for Agni, Falcon of the sky: Will he not give us of his wealth?

p: Whose lories when he glows in front of sacrite are fair to seelike wealth of one with hero sons.

p: May he enjoy this hallowed gift, Agni accept our songs, who bears Oblations, best of worshippers.

p: Lord of the house, whom men must seek, we set thee down, O Worshipped Onel Bright, rich in heroes, Agni! God

p: Shine forth at night and morn: through thee with fires are we provided well. Thou, rich in heroes, art our Friend.

p: The men come near thee for their gain, the singers with their songs of praise: Speech, thousandfold, comes near to thee.

p: Bright, purifier, meet for praise, Immortal with refulgent glow, Agni drives Raksasas away.

p: As such, bring us abundant wealth, young Child of Strength, for this thou canst May Bhaga give us what is choice.

p: Thou, Agni, givest hero fame: Bhaga and Savitar the Deva, and Did give us what is good.

p: Agni, preserve us from distress: consume our enemies, O Deva, Eternal, with the hottest flames.

p: And, irresistible, be thou a mighty iron fort to us, with hundred walls for man's defence.

p: Do thou preserve us, eve and morn, from sorrow, from the wicked men, infallible! by day and night.

hymns.title: HYMN XVI. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: WITH this my reverent hymn I call Agni for you, the Son of Strength, Dear, wisest envoy, served with noble offering, immortal messenger of all.

p: His two red horses, all-supporting, let him yoke: let him, well-worshipped, urge them fast. Then hath  'the offering good prayers and happy end, and heavenly gift of wealth to men.

p: The flame of him the Bountiful, the Much-invoked, hath mounted up, and his red-coloured smoke-clouds reach and touch the sky: the men are kindling Agni well.

p: Thee, thee Most Glorious One we make our messenger. Bring the Devas hither to the feast. Give us, O Son of Strength, all food that fcedeth man: give that for which we pray to thee.

p: Thou, Agni, art the homestead's Lord, our Herald at  'the offering. Lord of all boons, thou art the Cleanser and a Sage. Pay worship, and enjoy the good.

p: Give riches to  'the offeringr, O Most Wise, for thou art he who granteth wealth. Inspire with zeal each priest at this our solemn rite; all who are skilled in singing praise.

p: O Agni who art worshipped well, dear let our princes he to thee, Our wealthy patrons who are governors of men, who part, as gifts, their stalls of kine.

p: They in whose home, her hand bearing the sacred oil, Ila sits down well-satisfied- Guard them, Victorious Deva, from slander and from harm. give us a refuge famed afar.

p: Do thou, a Monk with pleasant tongue, most wise, and very near to us, Agni, bring riches hither to our liberal chiefs, and speed the oflering of our gifts.

p: They who bestow as bounty plenteous wealth of steeds, moved by desire of great renown- Do thou with saving help preserve them from distress, most Youthful! with a hundred forts.

p: The Deva who gives your wealth demands a full libation poured to him. Pour ye it forth, then fill the vessel full again: then doth the Deva.pay heed to you.

p: Him have the Devas appointed Monk of offering, oblation-bearer, passing wise. Agni gives wealth and valour to the worshipper, to folk who offer up their gifts.

hymns.title: HYMN XVII. Agni.
hymns.text:
p: AGNI, be kindled well with proper fuel, and let the grass be scattered wide about thee.

p: Let the impatient Portals be thrown open bring thou the Devas impatient to come hither.

p: Taste, Agni: serve the Devas with our oblation. Offer good offers, Jatavedas!

p: Let Jatavedas pay fair offers, worship andgratify the Devas Immortal.

p: Wise Deva, win for us things that are all-goodly, and let the prayers, we pray today be fruitful.

p: Thee, even thee, the Son of Strength, O Agni, those Devas have made the bearer of oblations.

p: To thee the Go. May we perform our worship: do thou, besought, grant us abundant riches.

hymns.title: HYMN XVIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: ALL is with thee, O Indra, all the treasure.s which erst our fathers won who sang thy praises. With thee are milch-kine good to milk, and horses: best winner thou of riches for the pious.

p: For like a King among his wives thou dwellest: with glories, as a Sage, surround and help us. Make us, thy servants, strong for wealth, and honour our songs wirth kine and steeds and decoration.

p: Here these our holy hymns with joy and gladness in pious emulation have approached thee. Hitherward come thy path that leads to riches. May we find shelter in thy favour, indra.

p: Vasistha hath poured forth his prayers, desiring to milk thee like a cow in goodly pasture. All these my people call thee Lord of cattle. May Indra. come unto the prayer we offer.

p: What though the floods spread widely, indra made them shallow and easy for Sudas to traverse. He, worthy of our praises, caused the Simyu, foe of our hymn, to curse the rivers' fury.

p: Eager for spoil was Turvasa Purodas, fain to win wealth, like fishes urged by hunger. The Bhrgus and the Druhyus quickly listened: friend rescued friend mid the two distant peoples.

p: Together came the Pakthas, the Bhalanas, the Alinas, the Sivas, the Visanins. Yet to the Trtsus came the Arya's Comrade, through love of spoil and heroes' war, to lead them.

p: Fools, in their folly fain to waste her waters, they parted inexhaustible Parusni. Lord of the Earth, he with his might repressed them: still lay the herd and the affrighted herdsman.

p: As to their goal they sped to their destruetion: they sought Parusni; e’en the swift returned not. Indra abandoned, to Sudas the manly, the swiftly flying foes, unmanly babblers.

p: They went like kine unherded from the pasture, each clinging to a friend as chance directed. They who drive spotted steeds, sent down by Prsni, gave ear, the Warriors and the harnessed horses.

p: The King who scattered one-and-twenty people of both Vaikarna tribes through lust of glory- As the skilled priest clips grass within the chamber, so hath the Hero Indra, wrought their downfall.

p: Thou, thunder-armed, o’erwhelmedst in the waters famed ancient Kavasa and then the Druhyu. Others here claiming friendship to their friendship, devoted unto thee, in thee were joyful.

p: Indra at once with conquering might demolished all their strong places and their seven castles. The goods of Anu's son he gave to Trtsu. May we in offering conquer scorned Puru.

p: The Anavas and Druhyus, seeking booty, have slept, the sixty hundred, yea, six thousand, and six-and-sixty heroes. For the pious were all these mighty exploits done by Indra.

p: These Trtsus under Indra's careful guidance came speeding like loosed waters rushing downward. The foemen, measuring exceeding closely, abandoned to Sudas all their provisions.

p: The hero's side who drank the dressed oblation, indra's denier, far o’er earth he scattered. Indra brought down the fierce destroyer's fury. He gave them various roads, the path's Controller.

p: E’en with the weak he wrought this matchless exploit: e’en with a goat he did to death a lion. He pared the pillar's angles with a needle. Thus to Sudas Indra gave all provisions.

p: To thee have all thine enemies submitted: e’en the fierce Bheda hast thou made thy subject. Cast down thy sharpened thunderbolt, O Indra, on him who harms the men who sing thy praises.

p: Yamuna and the Trtsus aided Indra. There he stripped Bheda bare of all his treasure.s. The Ajas and the Sigrus and the Yaksus brought in to him as tribute heads of horses.

p: Not to be scorned, but like Dawns past and recent, O Indra, are thy favours and thy riches. Devaka, Manyamana's son, thou slewest, and smotest Sambara from the lofty mountain.

p: They who, from home, have gladdened thee, thy servants Parasara, Vasistha, Satayatu, Will not forget thy friendship, liberal Giver. So shall the days dawn prosperous for the princes.

p: Monk-like, with praise, I move around the altar, earning Paijavana's reward, O Agni, Two hundred cows from Devavan's descendant, two chariots from Sudas with mares to draw them.

p: Gift of Paijavana, four horses bear me in foremost place, trained steeds with pearl to deck them. Sudas's brown steeds, firmly-stepping, carry me and my son for progeny and glory.

p: Him whose fame spreads between wide earth and heaven, who, as dispenser, gives each chief his portion, Seven flowing Rivers glorify like Indra. He slew Yudhyamadhi in close encounter.

p: Attend on him O ye heroic Maruts as on Sudas's father Divodasa. Further Paijavana's desire with favour. Guard faithfully his lasting firm dominion.

hymns.title: HYMN XIX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: HE like a bull with sharpened horns, terrific, singly excites and agitates all the people: Thou givest him who largely pours libations his goods who pours not, for his own possession.

p: Thou, verily, indra, gavest help to Kutsa, willingly giving car to him in battle, when, aiding Arjuneya, thou subduedst to him both Kuyava and the Dasa Susna.

p: O Bold One, thou with all thine aids hast boldly holpen Sudas whose offerings were accepted, puru in winning land and subduing foemen, and Trasadasyu son of Purukutsa.

p: At the Devas’ banquet, hero-souled! with Heroes, Lord of Bay Steeds, thou slewest many foemen. Thou sentest in swift death to sleep the Dasyu, both Cumuri and Dhuni, for Dabhiti.

p: These were thy mighty powers that, Thunder-wielder, thou swiftly crushedst nine-and-ninety castles: Thou capturedst the hundredth in thine onslaught; thou slewest Namuci, thou slewest Vrtra.

p: Old are the blessings, indra, which thou gavest Sudas the worshipper who brought oblations. For thee, the Strong, I yoke thy strong Bay Horses. May our meditations reach thee and win strength, most Mighty!

p: Give us not up, Lord of Bay Horses, Victor, in this thine own assembly, to the wicked. Deliver us with true and faithful assists: dea. May we be to thee among the princes.

p: May we men, Maghavan, the friends thou lovest, near thee be joyful under thy protection. Fain to fulfil the wish of Atithigva humble. the pride of Turvasa and Yadva.

p: Swiftly, in truth about thee men skilled in hymning sing their songs and praises. ' Elect us also into their assembly who by their calls on thee despoiled the niggards.

p: Thine are these lauds, O manliest of heroes, lauds which revert to us and give us riches. Favour these, indra, when they fight with faemen, as Friend and Hero and the heroes' Helper.

p: Now, lauded for thine aid. Heroic Indra, sped by our meditation, wax mighty in thy body. Apportion to us strength and habitations. Ye Devas, protect us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: STRONG, Deva.y-natured, born for hero exploit, man's Friend, hedoth whatever deed he willeth. Saving us e’en from great transgression, indra, the Youthful, visiteth man's home with favour.

p: Waxing greatness Indra slayeth Vrtra: the Hero with his aid hath helped the singer. He gave Sudas wide room and space, and often hath granted wealth to him who brought oblations.

p: Soldier unchecked, war-rousing, battling Hero, unconquered from of old, victorious ever, indra the very strong hath scattered armies; yea, he hath slain each foe who fought against him.

p: Thou with thy greatness hast filled full, O Indra, even both the worlds with might, O thou Most Mighty. Lord of Bays, indra, brandishing his thunder, is gratified with Soma at the banquet.

p: A Bull begat the Bull for joy of battle, and a strong Mother brought forth him the manly. He who is Chief of men, their armies' Leader, is strong Hero, bold, and fain for booty.

p: The people falter not, nor suffer sorrow, who win themselves this Deva's terrific spirit. He who with offers worships Indra is lord of wealth, law-born and law's protector.

p: Whene’er the elder fain would help the younger the greater cometh to the lesser's present. Shall the Immortal sit aloof' inactive? O Wondrous Indra, bring us wondrous riches.

p: Thy dear folk, indra, who present oblations, are, in chief place, thy friends, O Thunder-wielder. May we be best content in this thy favour, sheltered by One who subdues not, but preserves us.

p: To thee the mighty hymn hath clamoured loudly, and, Maghavan, the eloquent hath besought thee. Desire of wealth hath come upon thy singer: help us then, gakra, to our share of riches.

p: Place us by food which thou hast given, O Indra, us and the wealthy patrons who command us. Let thy great power bring good to him who lauds thee. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: PRESSED is the juice divine with milk commingled: thereto hath Indra ever been accustomed. We wake thee, Lord of Bays, with offers: mark this our laud in the wild joy of Soma.

p: On to the rite they move, the grass they scatter, these Soma-drinkers eloquent in synod. Hither, for men to grasp, are brought the press-stones, far-thundering, famous, strong, that wait on heroes.

p: Indra, thou settest free the many waters that were encompassed. Hero, by the Dragon. Down rolled, as if on chariots borne, the rivers: through fear of thee all things created tremble.

p: Skilled in all manly deeds the Deva.terrific hath with his weapons mastered these opponents. Indra in rapturous joy shook down their castles he slew them in his might, the Thunder-wielder.

p: No evil spirits have impelled us, indra, nor fiends, O Mightiest Deva, with their devices. Let our true Deva.subdue the hostile rabble: let not the lewd approach our holy worship.

p: Thou in thy strength surpassest Earth and Heaven: the regions comprehend not all thy greatness. With thine own power and might thou slewest Vrtra: no foe hath found the end of thee in battle.

p: Even the earlier Deities submitted their powers to thy supreme divine dominion. Indra wins wealth and deals it out to other's: men in the strife for booty call on Indra.

p: The humble hath invoked thee for protection, thee, Lord of great felicity, O Indra. Thou with a hundred aids hast been our Helper: one who brings gifts like thee hath his defender.

p: May we, O Indra, be thy friends forever, eagerly, Conqueror, yielding greater homage. May, through thy grace, the strength of us who battle quell in the shock the onset of the foeman.

p: Place us by food which thou hast given, O Indra, us and the wealthy patrons who command us. Let thy great power bring good to him who lauds thee. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXII Indra.
hymns.text:
p: DRINK Soma, Lord of Bays, and let it cheer thee: Indra, the stone, like a well guided courser, Directed by the presser's arms hath pressed it.

p: So let the draught of joy, thy dear companion, by which, O Lord of Bays, thou slayest foemen, Delight thee, indra, Lord of princely treasure.s.

p: Mark closely, Maghavan, the words I utter, this eulogy recited by Vasistha: Accept the prayers I offer at thy banquet.

p: Hear thou the call of the juice-drinking press-stone: hear thou the Brahman's hymn who sings and lauds thee. Take to thine inmost self these adorations.

p: I know and ne’er forget the hymns and praises of thee, the Conqueror, and thy strength immortal. Thy name I ever utter. Self-Refulgent

p: Among mankind many are thy libations, and many a time the pious sageinvokes thee. O Maghavan, be not long distant from us.

p: All these libations are for thee, O Hero: to thee I offer these my meditations. that strengthen. Ever, in every place, must men invoke thee.

p: Never do men attain, O Wonder-Worker, thy greatness, Mighty One, who must be lauded, Nor, indra, thine heroic power and bounty.

p: Among all Rsis, indra, old and recent, who have engendered hymns as sacred singers, Even with us be thine auspicious friendships. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: PRAYERS have been offered up through love of glory: Vasistha, honour Indra in the battle. He who with might extends through all existence hears words which I, his faithful servant, utter.

p: A cry was raised which reached the Devas, O Indra, a cry to them to send us strength in combat. None among men knows his own life's duration: bear us in safety over these our troubles.

p: The Bays, the booty-seeking car I harness: my meditations have reached him who accepts them gladly. Indra, when he had slain resistless foemen, forced with his might the two world-halves asunder.

p: Like barren cows, moreover, swelled the waters: the singen sought thy holy rite, O Indra. Come unto us as with his team comes Vayu: thou, through our solemn hymns bestowest booty.

p: May these gladdening draughts rejoice thee, indra, the Mighty, very bounteous to the singer. Alone among the Devas thou pitiest mortals: O Hero, make thee glad at this libation.

p: Thus the Vasisthas glorify with praises Indra, the Powerful whose arm wields thunder. Praised. May he guard our wealth in kine and heroes. Ye Devas, preserve us evermore with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIV. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: A HOME is made for thee to dwell in, indra: O Much-invoked, go thitherwith the heroes. That thou, to prosper us. Mayst be our Helper, vouchsafe us wealth, rejoice with draughts of Soma.

p: Indra, thy wish, twice-strong, is comprehended: pressed is the Soma, poured are pleasant juices. This hymn of praise, from loosened tongue, made perfect, draws Indra to itself with loud invoking.

p: Come, thou Impetuous; Deva, from earth or heaven; come to our holy grass to drink the Soma. Hither to me let thy Bay Horses bring thee to listen to our hymns and make thee joyful.

p: Come unto us with all thine aids, accordant, Lord of Bay Steeds, accepting our devotions, Fair-helmeted, o’ercoming with the mighty, and lending us the strength of bulls, O Indra.

p: As to the chariot pole a vigorous courser, this laud is brought to the great strong Upholder. This hymn solicits wealth of thee: in heaven, as ’twere above the sky, set thou our glory.

p: With precious things. O Indra, thus content us. May we attain to thine exalted favour. Send our chiefs plenteous food with hero children. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXV. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: WHEN with thy mighty help, O potent Indra, the armies rush together in their fury. When from the strong man's arm the lightning flieth, let not the mind go forth to side with others.

p: O Indra, where the ground is hard to traverse, smite down our foes, the mortals who assail us, Keep far from us the curse of the reviler: bring us accumulated store of treasure.s.

p: Deva.of the fair helm, give Sudas a hundred assists, a thousand blessings, and thy bounty. Strike down the weapon of our mortal foeman: bestow upon us splendid fame and riches.

p: I wait the power of one like thee, O Indra, gifts of a Helper such as thou art. Hero. Strong, Mighty Deva, dwell with me now and ever: Lord of Bay Horses, do not thou desert us.

p: Here are the Kutsas supplicating Indra for might, the Lord of Bays for Deva.sent conquest. Make our foes ever easy to be vanquished. May we, victorious, win the spoil, O Hero.

p: With precious things, O Indra, thus content us. May we attain to thine exalted favour. Send our chiefs plenteous food with hero children. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: SOMA unpressed ne’er gladdened liberal Indra, no juices pressed without a prayer have pleased him. I generate a laud that shall delight him, new and heroic, so that h. May hear us.

p: At every laud the Soma gladdens Indra: pressed juices please him as each psalm is chanted, what time the monks with one united effort call him to aid, as sons invoke their father.

p: These deeds he did; let him achieve new exploits, such as the monks declare at their libations. Indra hath taken and possessed all castles, like as one common husband doth his spouses.

p: Even thus have they declared him. Famed is Indra as Conqueror, sole distributer of treasure.s. Whose many assists come in close succession. May dear delightful benefits attend us.

p: Thus, to bring help to men, Vasistha laudeth Indra, the peoples' Hero, at libation. Bestow upon us strength and wealth in thousands. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: MEN call on Indra in the armed encounter that h. May make the hymns they sing decisive. Hero, rejoicing in thy might, in combat give us a portion of the stall of cattle,

p: Grant, indra Maghavan, invoked of many, to these my friends the strength which thou possessest. Thou, Maghavan, hast rent strong places open: unclose for us, Wise Deva, thy hidden bounty.

p: King of the living world, of men, is Indra, of all in varied form that earth containeth. Thence to the worshipper he giveth riches. May he enrich us also when we laud him.

p: Maghavan Indra, when we all invoke him, bountiful ever sendeth strength to aid us: Whose perfect guerdon, never failing, bringeth wealth to the men, to friends the thing they covet.

p: Quick, indra, give us room and way to riches, and let us bring thy mind to grant us treasure.s, that we may win us cars and Steeds and cattle. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXVIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: COME to our meditations, O Indra, thou who knowest: let thy Bay Steeds be yoked and guided hither. Though mortal men on every side invoke thee, still give thine ear to us, O All-impeller.

p: Thy greatness reacheth to our invocation, the sages' prayer which, potent Deva, thou guardest. What time thy hand, O Mighty, holds the thunder, awful in strength thou hast become resistless.

p: What time thou drewest both world-halves together, like heroes led by thee who call each other- For thou wast born for strength and high dominion-then e’en the active overthrew the sluggish.

p: Honour us in these present days, O Indra, for hostile men are making expiation. Our sin that sinless Varuna discovered, the Wondrous-Wise hath long ago forgiven.

p: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra, that h. May grant us gifts of ample riches, best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXIX Indra.
hymns.text:
p: THIS Soma hath been pressed for thee, O Indra: come hither, Lord of Bays, for this thou lovest. Drink of this fair, this well-effused libation: Maghavan, give us wealth when we implore thee.

p: Come to us quickly with thy Bay Steeds. Hero, come to our meditation, accepting our devotion. Enjoy thyself aright at this libation, and listen thou unto the prayers we offer.

p: What satisfaction do our hymns afford thee? When, Maghavan? Now let us do thee service. Hymns, only hymns, with love for thee, I weave thee: then hear, O Indra, these mine invocations.

p: They, verily, were also human beings whom thou wast wont to hear, those earlier sages. Hence I, O Indra Maghavan, invoke thee: thou art our Providence, even as a Father.

p: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra, that h. May grant us gifts of ample riches, best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXX. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: WITH power and strength, O Mighty Deva, approach us: be the augmenter, indra, of these riches; Strong Thunderer, Lord of men, for potent valour, for manly exploit and for high dominion.

p: Thee, worth invoking, in the din of battle, heroes invoke in fray for life and sunlight. Among all people thou art foremost fighter: give up our enemies to easy slaughter.

p: When fair bright days shall dawn on us, O Indra, and thou shalt bring thy banner near in battle, Agni the Asura shall sit as Herald, calling Devas hither for our great good fortune.

p: Thine are we, indra, thine, both these who praise thee, and those who give rich gifts, O Deva.and Hero. Grant to our princes excellent protection. May they wax old and still be strong and happy.

p: We will address this liberal Lord, this Indra that h. May grant us gifts of ample riches: Best favourer of the singer's prayer and praises. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXI. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: SING ye a song, to make him glad, to Indra, Lord of Tawny Steeds, Soma, O my friends.

p: To him the Bounteous say the laud, and let us glorify, as men May do, the Giver of true gifts.

p: O Indra, Lord of boundless might, for us thou winnest strength and kine, Thou winnest gold for us, Good Lord.

p: Faithful to thee we loudly sing, heroic Indra, songs to thee: Mark, O Indra, this act of ours.

p: Give us not up to man's reproach, to foeman's hateful calumny: In thee alone is all my strength.

p: Thou art mine ample coat of mail, my Champion, Vrtra-Slayer, thou: With thee for Friend I brave the foe.

p: Yea, great art thou whose conquering might two independent Powers confess. The Heaven, O India, and the Earth.

p: So let the voice surround thee, which attends the Maruts on their way, Reaching thee with the rays of light.

p: Let the ascending drops attain to thee, the Wondrous Deva, in heaven: Let all the folk bow down to thee.

p: Bring to the Wise, the Great, who waxeth mighty, your offerings, and make ready your devotion; To many clans he goeth, man's controller.

p: For Indra, the sublime, the far-pervading, have singers generated prayer and praises: The sages never violate his statutes.

p: The choirs have stablished Indra King forever, for victory, him whose anger is resistless: And, for the Bays' Lord, strengthened those he loveth.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: LET none, no, not thy worshippers, delay thee far away from us. Even from far away come thou unto our feast, or listen if already here.

p: For here, like flies on honey, these who pray to thee sit by the juice that they have poured. Wealth-craving singers have on Indra set their hope, as men set foot upon a car.

p: Longing for wealth I call on him, the Thunderer with the strong right hand, as a son calleth on his sire.

p: These Soma juices, mixed with curd, have been expressed for Indra here. Come with thy Bay Steeds, Thunder-wielder, to our home, to drink them till they make thee glad.

p: May he whose ear is open hear us. He is asked for wealth: will he despise our meditation? Him who bestows at once a hundred thousand gifts none shall restrain when he would give.

p: The hero never checked by men hath gained his strength through Indra, he Who presses out and pours his deep libations forth, O Vrtra conquerer, unto thee.

p: When thou dost drive the fighting men together be, thou Mighty One, the mighty's shield. May we divide the wealth of him whom thou hast slain: bring us, Unreachable, his goods.

p: For Indra, Soma-drinker, armed with thunder, press the Soma juice. Make ready your dressed meats: cause him to favour us. The Giver blesses him who gives.

p: Grudge not, ye Soma pourers; stir you, pay the rites, for wealth, to the great Conqueror. Only the active conquers dwells in peace, and thrives: not for the niggard are the Devas.

p: No one hath overturned or stayed the car of him who freely gives. The man whom Indra and the Marut host defend comes to a stable full of kine.

p: Indra, that man when fighting shall obtain the spoil, whose strong defender thou wilt be. Be thou the gracious helper. Hero I of our cars, be thou the helper of our men.

p: His portion is exceeding great like a victorious soldier's spoil. Him who is Indra, Lord of Bays, no foes subdue. He gives the Soma-pourer strength.

p: Make for the Holy Devas a hymn that is not mean, but well-arranged and fair of form. Even many snares and bonds subdue not him who dwells with Indra through his offering.

p: Indra, what mortal will attack the man who hath his wealth in thee? The strong will win the spoil on the decisive day through faith in thee, O Maghavan.

p: In battles with the foe urge on our mighty ones who give the treasure.s dear to thee, an. May we with our princes, Lord of Tawny Steeds! pass through all peril, led by thee.

p: Thine, indra, is the lowest wealth, thou cherishest the mid-most wealth, Thou ever rulest all the highest: in the fray for cattle none resisteth thee.

p: Thou art renowned as giving wealth to every one in all the battles that are fought. Craving protection, all these people of the earth, O Much-invoked, implore thy name.

p: If I, O Indra, were the Lord of riches ample as thine own, I should support the singer, Deva. who givest wealth! and not abandon him to woe.

p: Each day would I enrich the man who sang my praise, in whatsoever place he were. No kinship is there better, Maghavan, than thine: a father even is no more.

p: With Plenty for his true ally the active man will gain the spoil. Your Indra, Much-invoked, I bend with song, as bends a wright his wheel of solid wood.

p: A moral wins no riches by unworthy praise: wealth comes not to the niggard churl. Light is the task to give to one like me on the decisive day.

p: Like kine unmilked we call aloud. Hero, to thee, and sing thy praise, Looker on heavenly light, Lord of this moving world, Lord, indra, of what moveth not.

p: None other like to thee, of earth or of the heavens, hath been or ever will be born. Desiring horses, indra Maghavan! and kine, as men of might we call on thee.

p: Bring, indra, the Victorious Ones; bring, elder thou, the younger host. For, Maghavan, thou art rich in treasure.s from of old, and must be called in every fight.

p: Drive thou away our enemies, O Maghavan: make riches easy to be won. Be thou our good Protector in the strife for spoil: Cherisher of our friends be thou.

p: O Indra, give us wisdom as a sire gives wisdom to his sons. Guide us, O Much-invoked, in this our wa. May we still live and look upon the light.

p: Grant that no mighty foes, unknown, malevolent, unhallowed, tread us to the ground. With thine assistance. Hero. May we ass through all the waters that are rul`ng down.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIII Vasistha.
hymns.text:
p: THESE who wear hair-knots on the right, the movers of holy thought, white-robed, have won me over. I warned the men, when from the grass I raised me, Not from afar can my Vasisthas help you.

p: With Soma they brought Indra from a distance, Over Vaisanta, from the strong libation. Indra preferred Vasisthas to the Soma pressed by the son of Vayata, pasadyumna.

p: So, verily, with these he crossed the river, in company with these he slaughtered Bheda. So in the fight with the Ten Kings, Vasisthas! did Indra help Sudas through your devotions.

p: I gladly, men I with prayer prayed by our fathers have fixed your axle: ye shall not be injured: Since, when ye sang aloud the Sakvari verses, Vasisthas! ye invigorated Indra.

p: Like thirsty men they looked to heaven, in battle with the Ten Kings, surrounded and imploring. Then Indra heard Vasistha as he praised him, and gave the Trtsus ample room and freedom.

p: Like sticks and staves wherewith they drive the cattle, Stripped bare, the Bharatas were found defenceless: Vasistha then became their chief and leader: then widely. were the Trtsus' clans extended.

p: Three fertilize the worlds with genial moisture: three noble Creatures cast a light before them. Three that give warmth to all attend the morning. All these have they discovered, these Vasisthas.

p: Like the Sun's growing glory is their splendour, and like the sea's is their unflathomed greatness. Their course is like the wind's. Your laud, Vasisthas, can never be attained by any other.

p: They with perceptions of the heart in secret resort to that which spreads a thousand branches. The Apsaras brought hither the Vasisthas wearing the vesture spun for them by Yama.

p: A form of lustre springing from the lightning wast thou, when Varuna and Mitra s w thee. Tliy one and only birth was then, Vasistha, when from thy stock Agastya brought thee hither.

p: Born of their love for Urvasi, Vasistha thou, priest, art son of Varuna and Mitra; And as a fallen drop, in heavenly fervour, all the Devas laid thee on a lotus-blossorn.

p: He thinker, knower both of earth and heaven, endowed with many a gift, Destined to wear the vesture spun by Yama, sprang from the Apsaras to life, Vasistha.

p: Born at  'the offering, urged by adorations, both with a common flow bedewed the pitcher. Then from the midst thereof there rose up Mana, and thence they say was born the sage Vasistha.

p: He brings the bearer of the laud and Saman: first shall he speak bringing the stone for pressing. With grateful hearts in reverence approach him: to you, O Pratrdas, Vasistha cometh.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIV Devas.
hymns.text:
p: MAY our divine and brilliant hymn go forth, like a swift chariot wrought and fashioned well.

p: The waters listen as they flow along: they know the origin of heaven and earth.

p: Yea, the broad waters swell their flood ior him: of him strong heroes think amid their foes.

p: Set ye for him the coursers to the pole: like Indra Thunderer is the Golden-armed.

p: Arouse you, like the days, to offering speed gladly like a traveller on the way.

p: Go swift to battles, to  'the offering: set up a flag, a hero for the folk.

p: Up from his strength hath risen as ’twere a light: it bears the load as earth bears living things.

p: Agni, no demon I invoke the Devas: by law completing it, I form a hymn.

p: Closely albout you lay your heavenly song, and send your voice to where the Devas abide.

p: Varuna, Mighty, with a thousand eyes, beholds the paths wherein these rivers run.

p: He, King of kings, the glory of the floods, o’er all that liveth hath resistless sway.

p: May he assist us among all the tribes, and make the envier's praise devoid of light.

p: May the foes' threatening arrow pass us by. May he put far from us our bodies' sin.

p: Agni, oblation-cater, through our meditations aid us: to him our dearest laud is brought.

p: Accordant with the Devas choose for our Friend the Waters’ Child. May he be good to us.

p: With lauds I sing the Dragon born of floods: he sits beneath the streams in middle air.

p: Ne’e. May the Dragon of the Deep harm us: ne’er fail this faithful servant's offering.

p: To these our heroe. May they grant renown. May pious men march boldly on to wealth.

p: Leading great hosts, with fierce attacks of these, they burn their foes as the Sun burns the earth.

p: What time our wives draw near to us. May he, left-handed Tvastar, give us hero sons.

p: May Tvastar find our hymn acceptable, an. May Aramati, seeking wealth, be ours.

p: May they who lavish gifts bestow those treasure.s. May Rodasi and Varunani listen. May he, with the Varutris, be our refuge. May bountiful Tvastar give us store of riches.

p: May rich Mountains and the liberal Waters, s. May all Herbs that grow on ground, and Heaven, and Earth accordant with the Forest-Sovrans, and both the World-halves round about protect us.

p: To thi. May both the wide Worlds lend approval, and Varuna in heaven, whose Friend is Indra, may all the Maruts give consent, the Victors, that we may hold great wealth in firm possession.

p: May Indra, Varuna, Mitra, and Agni, Waters. Herbs, Trees accept the praise we offer. May we find refuge in the Marut's bosom. Protect us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXV, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: BEFRIEND us with their aids Indra and Agni, indra and Varuna who receive oblations! Indra and Soma give health, strength and comfort, indra and Pusan be our help in battle.

p: Auspicious Friends to us be Bhaga, Sathsa, auspicious be Purandhi aid all Riches; The blessing of the true and well-conducted, and Aryaman in many forms apparent.

p: Kind unto us he Maker and Sustainer, and the far-reaching Pair with Deva.like natures. Auspicious unto us be Earth and Heaven, the Mountain, and the Devas’ fair invocations.

p: Favour us Agni with his face of splendour, and Varuva and Mitra and the Asvins. Favour us noble actions of the pious, impetuous vita blow on us with favour.

p: Early invoked. May Heaven and Earth be friendly, and Air's mid-region good for us to look on. To u. May Herbs and Forest-Trees be gracious, gracious the Lord Victorious of the region.

p: Be the Deva.Indra with the Vasus friendly, and, with Adityas, Varuna who blesseth. Kind, with the Rudras, be the Healer Rudra, and, with the Dames. May Tvastar kindly listen.

p: Blest unto us be Soma, and devotions, blest be the Offering, the Stones for pressing. Blest be the fixing of the sacred Pillars, blest be the tender Grass and blest the Altar.

p: May the far-seeing Sun rise up to bless us: be the four Quarters of the sky auspicious. Auspicious be the firmly-seated Mountains, auspicious be the Rivers and the Waters.

p: May Adid through holy works be gracioas, an. May the Maruts, loud in song, be friendly. May Visnu give felicity, and Pusan, the Air that cherisheth our life, and Vayu.

p: Prosper us Savitar, the Deva who rescues, and let the radiant Mornings be propitious. Auspicious to all creatures be Parjanya, auspicious be the field's benign Protector.

p: May all the fellowship of Devas befriend us, Sarasvati, with Holy Thoughts, be gracious. Friendly be they, the Liberal Ones who seek us, yea, those who dwell in heaven, on earth, in waters.

p: May the great Lords of Truth protect and aid us: blest to us be our horses and our cattle. Kind be the pious skilful-handed Rbhus, kind be the Fathers at our invocations.

p: May Aja-Ekapad, the Deva, be gracious, gracious the Dragon of the Deep, and Ocean. Gracious be he the swelling Child of Waters, gracious be Prsni who hath Devas to guard her.

p: May the Rudras, Vasus, and Adityas accept the new hymn which we now are making. May all the Holy Ones of earth and heaven, and the Cow's offipring hear our invocation.

p: They who of Holy Devas are very holy, Immortal, knowing Law, whom man must worship. May these to-day give us broad paths to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVI. Devas
hymns.text:
p: LET the prayer issue from the seat of Order, for Surya with his beams hath loosed the cattle. With lofty ridges earth is far extended, and Agni's flame hath lit the spacious surface.

p: O Asuras, O Varuna and Mitra, this hymn to you, like food, anew I offer. One of you is a strong unerring Leader, and Mitra, speaking, stirreth men to labour.

p: The movements of the gliding wind come hither: like cows, the springs are filled to overflowing. Born in the station e’en of lofty heaven the Bull hath loudly bellowed in this region.

p: May I bring hither with my song, O Indra, wise Aryaman who yokes thy dear Bay Horses, Voracious, with thy noble car, O Hero, him who defeats the wrath of the malicious.

p: In their own place of offering adorers worship to gain long life and win his friendship. He hath poured food on men when they have praised him; be this, the dearest reverence, paid to Rudra.

p: Coming together, glorious, loudly roaring - Sarasvati, Mother of Floods, the seventh- With copious milk, with fair streams, strongly flowing, full swelling with the volume of their water;

p:  An. May the mighty Maruts, too, rejoicing, aid our devotion and protect our offspring. Let not swift-moving Aksara neglect us: they have increased our own appropriate riches,

p: Bring ye the great Aramati before you, and Pusan as the Hero of the synod, Bhaga who looks upon this hymn with favour, and, as our strength, the bountiful Purandbi.

p: May this our song of praise reach you, O Maruts, and Visnu guardian of the future infant. May they vouchsafe the singer strength for offspring. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVII, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: LET your best-bearing car that must be lauded, ne’er injured, bring you Vajas and Rbhuksans. Fill you, fair-helmeted! with mighty Soma, thrice-mixed, at our libations to delight you.

p: Ye who behold the light of heaven, Rbhuksans, give our rich patrons unmolested riches. Drink, heavenly-natured. at  'our offerings, and give us bounties for the hymns we sing you.

p: For thou, O Bounteous One, art used to giving, at parting treasure. whether small or ample. Filled full are both thine arms with great possessions: thy goodness keeps thee not from granting riches.

p: Indra, high-famed, as Vaja and Rbhuksans, thou goest working, singing to the dwelling. Lord of Bay Steeds, this da. May we Vasisthas offer our meditations to thee and bring oblations.

p: Thou winnest swift advancement for thy servant, through hymns, Lord of Bay Steeds, which thou hast favoured. For thee with friendly assist have we battled, and when, O Indra, wilt thou grant us riches?

p: To us thy monks a home, as ’twere, thou givest: when, indra wilt thou recognize our praises? May thy strong Steed, through our ancestral worship, bring food and wealth with heroes to our dwelling.

p: Though Nirrti the Deva reigneth round him, Autumns with food in plenty come to Indra. With three close Friends to length of days he cometh, he whom men let not rest at home in quiet.

p: Promise us gifts, O Savitar. May riches come unto us in Parvata's full bounty. May the Celestial Guardian still attend us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXVIII. Savitar.
hymns.text:
p: ON high hath Savitar, this Deva, extended the golden lustre which he spreads around him. Now, now must Bhaga be invoked by mortals, Lord of great riches who distributes treasure.s.

p: Rise up, O Savitar whose hands are golden, and hear this man while offering is offered, Spreading afar thy broad and wide effulgence, and bringing mortal men the food that feeds them.

p: Let Savitar the Deva.he hymned with praises, to whom the Vasus, even, all sing glory. Sweet be our lauds to him whose due is worship. May he with all protection guard our princes.

p: Even he whom Aditi the Deva praises, rejoicing in Deva.Savitar's incitement: Even he who praise the high imperial Rulers, Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman, sing in concert.

p: They who come emulous to our oblation, dispensing bounty, from the earth and heaven. May they and Ahibudhnya hear our calling: guard us Varutri with the Ekadhenus.

p: Thi. May the Lord of Life, entreated, grant us.the wealth which Savitar the Deva.possesses. The mighty calls on Bhaga for protection, on Bhaga calls the weak to give him riches.

p: Bless us the Vajins when we call, while slowly they move, strong Singers, to the Devas’ assembly. Crushing the wolf, the serpent, and the demons. May they completely banish all affliction.

p: Deep-skilled in Law eternal, deathless, Singers, O Vajins, help us in each fray for booty. Drink of this meath, he satisfied, be joyful: then go on paths which Devas are wont to travel.

hymns.title: HYMN XXXIX Devas.
hymns.text:
p: AGNI, erect, hath shown enriching favour: the flame goes forward to the Devas’ assembly. Like car-borne men the stones their path have chosen: let the priest, quickened, celebrate our worship.

p: Soft to the tread, their sacred grass is scattered: these go like Kings amid the band around them, At the folks early call on Night and Morning.Vayu, and Pusan with his team, to bless us.

p: Here on their path the noble Devas proceeded: in the wide firmament the Beauteous decked them. Bend your way hither, ye who travel widely: hear this our envoy who hath gone to meet you.

p: For they are holy aids at offers: all Devas approach the place of congregation. Bring these, desirous, to our worship, Agni, swift the Nisatyas, Bhaga, and Purandhi.

p: Agni, to these men's hymns, from earth, from heaven, bring Mitra, Varuna, indra, and Agni, and Aryaman, and Aditi, and Visnu. Sarasvati be joyful, and the Maruts.

p: Even as the holy wish, the gift is offered. May he, unsated, come when men desire him. Give never-failing ever-conquering riches: with Devas for our allie. May we be victors.

p: Now have both worlds been praised by the Vasisthas; and holy Mitra, Varuna, and Agni. May they, bright Deities, make our song supremest. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XL, Devas.
hymns.text:
p: BE gathered all the audience of the synod: let us begin their praise whose course is rapid. Whate’er Deva.Savitar this day produces. May we be where the Wealthy One distributes.

p: This, dealt from heaven . May both the Worlds vouchsafe us, and Varuna, indra, Aryaman, and Mitra. May Deva Aditi assign us riches, Vayu and Bhaga make them ours forever.

p: Strong be the man and full of power, O Maruts, whom ye, borne on by spotted coursers, favour. Him, too, Sarasvati and Agni further, and there is none to rob him of his riches.

p: This Varuna is guide of Law, he, Mitra, and Aryaman, the Kings, our work have finished. Divine and foeless Aditi quickly listens. May these deliver us unharmed from trouble.

p: With offerings I propitiate the branches of this swift-moving Deva, the bounteous Visnu. Hence Rudra gained his Rudra-strength: O Asvins, ye sought the house that hath celestial offerings.

p: Be not thou angry here, O glowing Pusan, for what Varutri and the Bounteous gave us. May the swift-moving Devas protect and bless us, and Vata send us rain, wha wanders round us.

p: Now have both worlds been praised by the Vasisthas, and holy Mitra, Varuna, and Agni. May they, bright Deities, make our song supremest. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLI. Bhaga.
hymns.text:
p: AGNI at dawn, and Indra we invoke at dawn, and Varuna and Mitra, and the Asvins twain. Bhaga at dawn, pusan, and Narasamsa, Soma at dawn, Rudra we will invoke at dawn.

p: We will invoke strong, early-conquering Bhaga, the Son of Aditi, the great supporter: Thinking of whom, the poor, yea, even the mighty, even the King himself says, Give me Bhaga.

p: Bhaga our guide, Bhaga whose gifts are faithful, favour this song, and give us wealth, O Bhaga. Bhaga, augment our store of kine and horses, Bhaga. May we be rich in men and heroes.

p: May felicity be ours at present, and when the day approaches, and at noontide; An. May we still, O Bounteous One, at sunset be happy in the Deities' loving-kindness.

p: May Bhaga verily be bliss-bestower, and through him, Devas. May happiness attend us. As such, O Bhaga, all with might invoke thee: as such be thou our Champion here, O Bhaga.

p: To this our worshi. May all Dawns incline them, and come to the pure place like Dadhikravan. As strong steeds draw a chario. May they bring us hitherward Bhaga who discovers treasure..

p: May blessed Mornings dawn on us forever, with wealth of kine, of horses, and of heroes, Streaming with all abundance, pouring fatness. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLII Devas.
hymns.text:
p: LET Brahmans and Angirases come forward, and let the roar of cloudy heaven surround us. Loud low the Milch-kine swimming in the waters: set be the stones that grace our holy service.

p: Fair, Agni, is thy long-known path to travel: yoke for the juice tfiy bay, thy ruddy horses, or red steeds. Hero-bearing, for the chamber. Seated, I call the Deities' generations.

p: They glorify y 'our offering with worship, yet the glad Monk near them is left unequalled. Bring the Devas hither, thou of many aspects: turn hitherward Aramati the Holy.

p: What time the Guest hath made himself apparent, at ease reclining in the rich man's dwelling, Agni, well-pleased, well-placed within the chamber gives to a house like this wealth worth the choosing.

p: Accept this offering of ours, O Agni; glorify it with Indra and the Maruts. Here on our grass let Night and Dawn be seated: bring longing Varuna and Mitra hither.

p: Thus hath Vasistha praised victorious Agni, yearning for wealth that giveth all subsistence. May he bestow on us food, strength, and riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIII Devas.
hymns.text:
p: SING out the pious at y 'our offerings to move with adorations Earth and Heaven- The Holy Singers, whose unmatched devotions, like a tree's branches, part in all directions.

p: Let offering proceed like some fleet courser: with one accord lift ye on high the ladles. Strew sacred grass meet for the solenm service: bright flames that love the Devas have mounted upward.

p: Like babes in arms reposing on their mother, let the Devas sit upon the grass's summit. Let general fire make bright the flame of worship: scorn us not, Agni, in the Devas’ assembly.

p: Gladly the Devas have let themselves be honoured, milking the copious streams of holy Order. The highest might to-day is yours, the Vasits': come ye, as many as ye are, one-minded.

p: So, Agni, send us wealth among the people. May we be closely knit to thee, O Victor, Unharmed, and rich, and taking joy together. Preserve us evermore, ye ods, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIV. Dadhikras.
hymns.text:
p: I CALL on Dadhikras, the first, to give you aid, the Asvins, Bhaga, Dawn, and Agni kindled well, indra, and Visnu, pusan, Narasamsa, Adityas. Heaven and Earth, the Waters, and the Light.

p: When, rising, to  'the offering we hasten, awaking Dadhikras with adorations. Seating on sacred grass the Deva Ila. let us invoke the sage swift-hearing Asvins.

p: While I am thus arousing Dadhikravan I speak to Agni, Earth, and Dawn, and Surya, the red, the brown of Varuna ever mindful. May they ward off from us all grief and trouble.

p: Foremost is Dadhikravan, vigorous courser, in forefront of the cars, his way he knoweth, closely allied with Surya and with Morning, Adityas, and Angirases, and Vasus.

p: May Dadhikras prepare the way we travel that we may pass along the path of Order. May Agni bear us, and the HeavenlyArmy: hear us all MightyOnes whom none deceiveth.

hymns.title: HYMN XLV. Savitar.
hymns.text:
p: MAY the Deva.Savitar, rich in goodly treasure.s, filling the region, borne by steeds, come hither, in his hand holding much that makes men happy, lulling to slumber and arousing creatures.

p: Golden, sublime, and easy in their motion, his arms extend unto the bounds of heaven. Now shall that mightiness of his he lauded: even Surya yields to him in active vigour.

p: May this Deva Savitar, the Strong and Mighty, the Lord of precious wealth, vouchsafe us treasure.s. May he, advancing his far-spreading lustre, bestow on us the food that feedeth mortals.

p: These songs praise Savitar whose tongue is pleasant, praise him whose arms are full, whose hands are lovely. High vital strength, and manifold. May he grant us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVI. Rudra.
hymns.text:
p: To Rudra bring these songs, whose bow is firm and strong, the self-dependent Deva with swiftly-flying shafts, the Wise, the Conqueror whom non. May overcome, armed with sharp-pointed weapons. May he hear our call.

p: He through his lordship thinks on beings of the earth, on heavenly beings through his high imperial sway. Come willingly to our doors that gladly welcome thee, and heal all sickness, Rudra., in our families.

p: May thy bright arrow which, shot down by thee from heaven, flieth upon the earth, pass us uninjured by. Thou, very gracious Deva, hast thousand medicines: inflict no evil on our sons or progeny.

p: Slay us not, nor abandon us, O Rudra let not thy noose, when thou art angry, seize us. Give us trimmed grass and fame among the living. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVII. Waters.
hymns.text:
p: MAY we obtain this day from you, O Waters, that wave of pure refreshment, which the pious Made erst the special beverage of Indra, bright, stainless, rich in sweets and dropping fatness.

p: May the Floods' Offspring, he whose course is rapid, protect that wave most rich in sweets, O Waters, that shall make Indra and the Vasus joyful. Thi. May we gain from you to-day, we pious.

p: All-purifying, joying in their nature, to paths of Devas the Devas move onward. They never violate the laws of Indra. Present the oil-rich offering to the Rivers.

p: Whom Surya with his bright beams hath attracted, and Indra dug the path for them to travel, may these Streams give us ample room and freedom. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLVIII. Rbhus.
hymns.text:
p: YE liberal Heroes, Vajas and Rbhuksans, come and delight you with our flowing Soma. May your strength, Vibhus, as ye come to meet us, turn hitherward your car that brings men profit.

p: May we as Rbhu with your Rbhus conquer strength with our strength, as Vibhus with the Vibhus. May Vaja aid us in the fight for booty, and helped by Indr. May we quell the foeman.

p: For they rule many tribes with high dominion, and conquer all their foes in close encounter. May Indra, Vibhvan, Vaja, and Rbhuksan destroy by turns the wicked foeman's valour.

p: Now, Deities, give us ample room and freedom: be all of you, one-minded, our protection. So let the Vasus grant us strength and vigour. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XLIX. Waters.
hymns.text:
p: FORTH from the middle of the flood the Waters-their chief the Sea-flow cleansing, never sleeping. Indra, the Bull, the Thunderer, dug their channels: here let those Waters, Devas, protect me.

p: Waters which come from heaven, or those that wander dug from the earth, or flowing free by nature, Bright, purifying, speeding to the Ocean, here let those Waters. Devas, protect me.

p: Those amid whom goes Varuna the Sovran, he who discriminates men's truth and falsehood- Distilling meath, the bright, the purifying, here let those Waters, Devas, protect me.

p: They from whom Varuna the King, and Soma, and all the Deities drink strength and vigour, they into whom Vaisvanara Agni entered, here let those Waters, Devas, protect Me.

hymns.title: HYMN L. Various Deities.
hymns.text:
p: O MITRA-VARUNA, guard and protect me here: let not that come to me which nests within and swells. I drive afar the scorpion hateful to the sight: let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

p: Eruption that appears upon the twofold joints, and that which overspreads the ankles and the knees, may the refulgent Agni banish far away let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

p: The poison that is formed upon the Salmali, that which is found in streams, that which the plants produce, All thi. May all the Devas banish and drive away: let not the winding worm touch me and wound my foot.

p: The steep declivities, the valleys, and the heights, the channels full of water, and the waterless- May those who swell with water, gracious Devas, never afflict us with the Sipada disease. May all the rivers keep us free from Simida.

hymns.title: HYMN LI. Adityas.
hymns.text:
p: THROUGH the Adityas’ most auspicious shelter, through their most recent succou. May we conquer. May they, the Mighty, giving ear, establish this offering, to make us free and sinless.

p: Let Aditi rejoice and the Adityas, Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman, most righteous. May they, the Guardians of the world, protect us, and, to show favour, drink this day our Soma.

p: All Universal Deities, the Maruts, all the Adityas, yea, and all the Rbhus, indra, and Agni, and the Asvins, lauded. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LII. Adityas.
hymns.text:
p: MAY we be free from every bond, Adityas! a castle among Devas and men, ye Vasus. Winning. May we win Varuna and Mitra, and, being. May we be, O Earth and Heaven.

p: May Varuna and Mitra grant this blessing, our Guardians, shelter to our seed and offspring. Let us not suffer for another's trespass. nor do the thing that ye, O Vasus, punish.

p: The ever-prompt Angirases, imploring riches from Savitar the Deva, obtained them. May our Father who is great and holy, and all the Devas, accordant, grant this favour.

hymns.title: HYMN LIII. Heaven and Earth.
hymns.text:
p: AS priest with solemn rites and adorations I worship Heaven and Earth, the High and Holy. To them, great Parents of the Devas, have sages of ancient time, singing, assigned precedence.

p: With newest hymns set in the seat of Order, those the Two Parents, born before all others, Come. Heaven and Earth, with the Celestial People, hither to us, for strong is your protection.

p: Yea. Heaven and Earth, ye hold in your possession full many a treasure. for the liberal giver. Grant us that wealth which comes in free abundance. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LIV. Vastospati.
hymns.text:
p: ACKNOWLEDGE us, O Guardian of the Homestead: bring no disease, and give us happy entrance. Whate’er we ask of thee, be pleased to grant it, and prosper thou quadrupeds and bipeds.

p: Protector of the Home, be our promoter: increase our wealth in kine and steeds, O Indu. May we be ever-youthful in thy friendship: be pleased in us as in his sons a father.

p: Through thy dear fellowship that bringeth welfare. May we be victors, Guardian of the Dwelling! Protect our happiness in rest and labour. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LV. Vastospati.
hymns.text:
p: VASTOSPATI, who killest all disease and wearest every form, be an auspicious Friend to us.

p: When, O bright Son of Sarama, thou showest, tawny-hued! thy teeth, they gleam like lances' points within thy mouth when thou wouldst bite; go thou to steep.

p: Sarama's Son, retrace thy way: bark at the robber and the thief. At Indra's singers barkest thou? Why dust thou seek to terrify us? Go to sleep.

p: Be on thy guard against the boar, and let the boar beware of thee. At Indra's singers barkest thou? Why dost thou seek to terrify us? Go to sleep.

p: Sleep mother, let the father sleep, sleep dog and master of the house. Let all the kinsmen sleep, sleep all the people who are round about.

p: The man who sits, the man who walks, and whosoever looks on us, Of these we closely shut the eyes, even as we closely shut this house.

p: The Bull who hath a thousand horns, who rises up from out the sea. By him the Strong and Mighty One we lull and make the people sleep.

p: The women sleeping in the court, lying without, or stretched on beds, the matrons with their odorous sweetsthese, one and all, we lull to sleep.

hymns.title: HYMN LVI. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: Wno are these radiant men in serried rank, Rudra's young heroes borne by noble steeds?

p: Verily no one knoweth whence they sprang: they, and they only, know each other's birth.

p: They strew each other with their blasts, these Hawks: they strove together, roaring like the wind.

p: A sage was he who knew these mysteries, what in her udder mighty Prsni bore.

p: Ever victorious, through the Maruts, be this band of Heroes, nursing manly strength,

p: Most bright in splendour, flectest on their way, close-knit to glory, strong with varied power.

p: Yea, mighty is your power and firm your strength: so, potent, with the Maruts, be the band.

p: Bright is your spirit, wrathful are your minds: your bold troop's minstrel is like one inspired.

p: Ever avert your blazing shaft from us, and let not your displeasure reach us here

p: Your dear names, conquering Maruts, we invoke, calling aloud till we are satisfied.

p: Well-armed, impetuous in their haste, they deck themselves, their forms, with oblations: to you, the pure, ornaments made of gold.
