p: Pure, Maruts, pure yourselves, are your oblations: to you, the pure, pure offering I offer. By Law they came to truth, the Law's observers, bright by their birth, and pure, and sanctifying.

p: Your rings, O Maruts, rest upon your shoulders, and chains of gold are twined upon your bosoms. Gleaming with drops of rain, like lightning-flashes, after your wont ye whirl about your weapons.

p: Wide in the depth of air spread forth your glories, far, most adorable, ye bear your titles. Maruts, accept this thousandfold allotment of household offering and household treasure..

p: If, Maruts, ye regard the praise recited here at this mighty singer invocation, vouchsafe us quickly wealth with noble heroes, wealth which no man uho hateth u. May injure.

p: The Maruts, fleet as coursers, while they deck them like youths spectators of a festal meeting, Linger, like beauteous colts, about the dwelling, like frisking calves, these who pour down the water.

p: May the Maruts help us and be gracious, bringing free room to lovely Earth and Heaven. Far be your bolt that slayeth men and cattle. Ye Vasus, turn yourselves to us with blessings.

p: The priest, when seated, loudly calls you, Maruts, praising in song your universal bounty. He, Bulls! who hath so much in his possession, free from duplicity, with hymns invokes you.

p: These Maruts bring the swift man to a stand-still, and strength with mightier strength they break and humble These guard the singer from the man who hates him and lay their sore displeasure on the wicked.

p: These Maruts rouse even the poor and needy: the Vasus love him as an active champion. Drive to a distance, O ye Bulls, the darkness: give us full store of children and descendants.

p: Never, O Maruts. May we lose your bounty, nor, car-borne Lords! be hitidmost when ye deal it. Give us a share in that delightful treasure., the genuine wealth that, Bulls! is your possession.

p: What time the men in fury rush together for running streams, for pastures, and for houses. Then, O ye Maruts, ye who spring from Rudra, be our protectors in the strife with foemen.

p: Full many a deed ye did for our forefathers worthy of lauds which, even of old, they sang you. lle strong man, with the Maruts, wins in battle, the charger, with the Maruts, gains the booty.

p: Ours, O ye Maruts, be the vigorous Hero, the Lord Divine of men, the strong Sustainer, with whom to fair lands we may cross the waters, and dwell in our own home with you beside us.

p: May Indra, Mitra, Varuna and Agni, Waters, and Plants, and Trees accept our praises. May we find shelter in the Marut's bosom. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LVII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: YEA, through the power of your sweet juice, ye Holy! the Marut host is glad at offers. They cause even spacious heaven and earth to tremble, they make the spring flow when they come, the Mighty.

p: The Maruts watch the man who sings their praises, promoters of the thought of him who worships. Seat you on sacred grass in our assembly, this day, with friendly minds, to share the banquet.

p: No others gleam so brightly as these Maruts with their own forms, their golden gauds, their weapons. With all adornments, decking earth and heaven, they heighten, for bright show, their common splendour.

p: Far from us be your blazing dart, O Maruts, when we, through human frailty, sin against you. Let us not he exposed to that, ye Holy! May your most loving favour still attend us.

p: May even what we have done delight the Maruts Ones, the bright, the purifying. Further us, O ye Holy, with your kindness: advance us mightily that we may prosper.

p: An. May the Maruts, praised by all their titles. Heroes, enjoy the taste of our oblations. Give us of Amrta for the sake of offspring: awake the excellent fair stores of riches.

p: Hither, ye Maruts, praised, with all your assists, with all felicity come to our princes, who, of themselves, a hundredfold increase us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LVIII. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: SING to the troop that pours down rain in common, the Mighty Company of celestial nature. They make the world-halves tremble with their greatness: from depths of earth and sky they reach to heaven.

p: Yea, your birth, Maruts, was with wild commotion, ye who move swiftly, fierce in wrath, terrific. Ye all-surpassing in your might and vigour, each looker on the light fears at your coming.

p: Give ample vital power unto our princes let our fair praises gratify the Maruts. As the way travelled helpeth people onward, so further us with your delightful assists.

p: Your favoured singer counts his wealth by hundreds: the strong steed whom ye favour wins a thousand. The Sovran whom ye aid destroys the foeman. May this your gift, ye Shakers, be distinguished.

p: I call, as such, the Sons of bounteous Rudra: will not the Maruts turn again to us ward? What secret sin or open stirs their anger, that we implore the Swift Ones to forgive us.

p: This eulogy of the Bounteous hath been spoken: accept, ye Maruts, this our hymn of praises. Ye Bulls, keep those who hate us at a distance. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LIX. Maruts.
hymns.text:
p: WHOMSO ye rescue here and there, whomso ye guide, O Deities, to him give shelter, Agni, Mitra, Varuna, ye Maruts, and thou Aryaman.

p: Through your kind favour, Devas, on some auspicious day, the worshipper subdues his foes. That man increases home and strengthening ample food who brings you offerings as ye list.

p: Vasistha will not overlook the lowliest one among you all. O Maruts, of our Soma juice effused to-day drink all of you with eager haste.

p: Your assist in the battle injures not the man to whom ye. Heroes, grant your gifts. May your most recent favour turn to us again. Come quickly, ye who fain would drink.

p: Come hitherward to drink the juice, O ye whose bounties give you joy. These offerings are for you, these, Maruts, I present. Go not to any place but this.

p: Sit on our sacred grass, be graciously inclined to give the wealth for which we long, to take delight, ye Maruts, Friends of all, with Svaha, in sweet Soma juice.

p: Decking the beauty of their forms in secret the Swans with purple backs have flown down hither. Around me all the Company hath settled, like joyous Heroes glad in our libation.

p: Maruts, the man whose wrath is hard to master, he who would subdue us ere we think, O Vasus, may he be tangled in the toils of mischief; smite ye him down with your most flaming weapon.

p: O Maruts, ye consuming Devas, enjoy this offering brought for you, to help us, ye who subdue the foe.

p: Sharers of household offering, come, Maruts, stay not far away, that y. May help us, Bounteous Ones.

p: Here, Self-strong Maruts, yea, even here. ye Sages with your sunbright skins I dedicate y 'our offering.

p: Tryambaka we worship, sweet augmenter of prosperity. As from its stem the cucumber, s. May I be released from death, not reft of immortality.

hymns.title: HYMN LX. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: WHEN thou, O Sun, this day, arising sinless, shalt speak the truth to Varuna and Mitra, O Aditi. May all the Deities love us, and thou, O Aryaman, while we are singing.

p: Looking on man, O Varuna and Mitra, this Sun ascendeth up by both the pathways, Guardian of all things fixt, of all that moveth, beholding good and evil acts of mortals.

p: He from their home hath yoked the Seven gold Coursers who, dropping oil and fatness, carry Surya. Yours, Varuna and Mitra, he surveyeth the worlds and living creatures like a herdsman.

p: Your coursers rich in store of sweets have mounted: to the bright ocean Surya hath ascended, for whom the Adityas make his pathway ready, Aryaman, Mitra, Varuna, accordant.

p: For these, even Aryaman, Varuna and Mitra, are the chastisers of all guile and falsehood. These, Aditi's Sons, infallible and mighty, have waxen in the home of law Eternal.

p: These, Mitra, Varuna whom none deceiveth, with great power quicken even the fool to wisdom, and, wakening, moreover, thoughtful insight, lead it by easy paths o’er grief and trouble.

p: They ever vigilant, with eyes that close not, caring for heaven and earth, lead on the thoughtless. Even in the river's bed there is a shallow. across this broad expans. May they conduct us.

p: When Aditi and Varuna and Mitra, like guardians, give Sudas their friendly shelter, Granting him sons and lineal succession, let us not, bold ones! move the Devas to anger.

p: May he with ofierings purify the altar from any stains of Varuna's reviler. Aryaman save us us all those who hate us: give room and freedom to Sudas, ye Mighty.

p: Hid from our eyes is their resplendent meeting: by their mysterious might they hold dominion. Heroes! we cry trembling in fear before you, even in the greatness of your power have mercy.

p: He who wins favour for his prayer by worship, that h. May gain him strength and highest riches, that good man's mind the MightyOnes will follow: they have brought comfort to his spacious dwelling.

p: This priestly task, Devas! Varuna and Mitra! hath been performed for you at offers. Convey us safely over every peril. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXI. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: O VARUNA and Mitra, Surya spreading the beauteous light of you Twain Devas ariseth. He who beholdetb all existing creatures observetb well the zeal that is in mortals.

p: The holy sage, renowned afar, directeth his hymns to you, O Varuna and Mitra. He whose devotions, sapient Devas, ye favour so that ye fill, as ’twere, with power his autumns.

p: From the wide earth, O Varuna and Mitra from the great lofty heaven, ye, Bounteous Givers, - Have in the fields and houses set your warder-, who visit every spot and watch unceasing.

p: I praise the strength of Varuna and Mitra that strength, by mightiness, keeps both worlds asunder. Heroless pass the months of the ungodly he who loves offering makes his home enduring.

p: Steers, all infallible are these your people in whom no wondrous thing is seen, no worship. Guile follows close the men who are untruthful: no secret. May be hidden from your knowledge.

p: I will exalt y 'our offering with homage: as priest, I, Mitra and Varuna, invoke you. May these new hymns and prayers that I have fashioned delight you to the profit of the singer.

p: This priestly task, Devas! Varuna and Mitra! hath been performed for you at offers. Convey us safely over every peril. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXII. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: SURYA hath sent aloft his beams of splendour o’er all the tribes of men in countless places. Together with the heaven he shines apparent, formed by his Makers well with power and wisdom.

p: So hast thou mounted up before us, Surya, through these our praises, with fleet dappled horses. Declare us free from all offence to Mitra, and Varuna, and Aryaman, and Agni.

p: May holy Agni, Varuna, and Mitra send down their riches upon us in thousands. May they, the Bright Ones, make our praise-song perfect, and, when we laud them, grant us all our wishes.

p: O undivided Heaven and Earth, preserve us, us, Lofty Ones! your nobIy-born descendants. Let us not anger Varuna, nor Vayu, nor him, the dearest Friend of mortals, Mitra.

p: Stretch forth your arms and let our lives be lengthened: with fatness dew the pastures of our cattle. Ye Youthful, make us famed among the people: hear, These mine invocations.

p: Now Mitra, Varuna, Aryaman vouchsafe us freedom and room, for us and for our children. May we find paths all fair and good to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIII. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: COMMON to all mankind, auspicious Surya, he who beholdeth all, is mounting upward; The Deva, the eye of Varuna and Mitra, who rolled up darkness like a piece of leather.

p: Surya's great ensign, restless as the billow, that urgeth men to action, is advancing: Onward he still would roll the wheel well-rounded, which Etasa, harnessed to the carpole, moveth.

p: Refulgent from the bosom of the Mornings, he in Whom singers take delight ascendeth. This Savitar, Deva, is my chief joy and pleasure, who breaketh not the universal statute.

p: Golden, far-seeing, from the heaven he riseth: far is his goal, he hasteth on resplendent. Men, verily, inspirited by Surya speed to their aims and do the work assigned them.

p: Where the irrunortals have prepared his pathway he flieth through the region like a falcon. With homage and oblations will we serve you, O Mitra and Varuna, when the Sun hath risen.

p: Now Mitra, Varuna, Aryaman vouchsafe us freedom and room, for us and for our children. May we find paths all fair and good to travel. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIV. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: YE Twain who rule, in heaven and earth, the region, clothed be your clouds in robes of oil and fatness. May the imperial Varuna, and Mitra, and high-born Aryaman accept our presents.

p: Kings, guards of rrtighty everlasting Order, come hitherward, ye Princes, Lords of Rivers. Send us from heaven, O Varuna and Mitra, rain and sweet food, ye who pour down your bounties.

p: May the dear Deva, and Varuna and Mitra conduct us by the most effective pathways, that foe. May say unto Sudas our chieftain, may, we, too, joy in food with Devas to guard us.

p: Him who hath wrought for you this car in spirit, who makes the song rise upward and sustains it, bedew with fatness, Varuna nd Mitra ye Kings, make glad the pleasant dwelling-places.

p: To you this laud, O Varuna and Mitra is offered like bright Soma juice to Vayu. Favour our songs of praise, wake thought and spirit. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXV. Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: WITH hymns I call you, when the Sun hath risen, Mitra, and Varuna whose thoughts are holy, whose Power Divine, supreme and everlasting, comes with good heed at each man's supplication.

p: For they are Asuras of Devas, the friendly make, both of you, our lands exceeding fruitful. May we obtain you, Varuna and Mitra, wherever Heaven and Earth and day. May bless us.

p: Bonds of the sinner, they bear many nooses: the wicked mortal hardl. May escape them. Varuna-Mitra. May your path of Order bear us o’er trouble as a boat o’er waters.

p: Come, taste our offering, Varuna and Mitra: bedew our pasture wil sweet food and fatness. Pour down in plenty here upon the people the choicest of your fair celestial water.

p: To you this laud, O Varuna and Mitra, is offered, like bright Soma juice to Vayu. Favour our songs of praise, wake thought and spirit. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVI Mitra and Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: LET our strong hymn of praise go forth, the laud of Mitra and Varuna, with homage to that high-born Pair;

p: The Two exceeding wise, the Sons of Daksa, whom the gods ordained For lordship, excellently great.

p: Such, Guardians of our homes and us, O Mitra and Varuna, fulfil The thoughts of those who sing your praise.

p: So when the Sun hath risen to-day. May sinless Mitra, Aryaman, Bhaga, and Savitar sendus forth.

p: May this our home be guarded well forward, ye Bounteous, on the way, who bear us safely o’er distress.

p:  And those Self-reigning, Aditi, whose statute is inviolate, the Kings who rule a vast domain.

p: Soon as the Sun hath risen, to you, to Mitra and Varuna, I sing, and Aryarnan who subdues the foe.

p: With wealth of gol. May this my song bring unmolested power and might, and, Brahmans, gain  'the offering.

p: May we be thine, Deva.Varuna, and with our princes, Mitra, thine. Food and Heaven's light will we obtain.

p: Many are they who strengthen Law, Sun-eyed, with Agni for their tongue, they who direct the three great gatherings with their thoughts, yea, all things with surpassing might.

p: They who have stablished year and month and then the day, night, offering and holy verse, Varuna, Mitra, Aryarnan, the Kings, have won dominion which non els. May gain.

p: So at the rising of the Sun we think of you with hymns to-day, Even as Varuna, Mitra, Aryaman deserve: ye are the charioteers of Law.

p: True to Law, born in Law the strengtheners of Law, terrible, haters of the false, in their felicity which gives the best defenc. May we men and our princes dwell.

p: Uprises, on the slope of heaven, that marvel that attracts die sight As swift celestial Etasa bears it away, prepared forevery eye to see.

p: Lord of each single head, of fixt and moving things, equally through the whole expanse, the Seven sister Bays bear Surya on his car, to bring us wealth and happiness.

p: A hundred autumn. May we see that bright Eye, Deva.ordained, arise A hundred autumn. May we live.

p: Infallible through your wisdom, come hither, resplendent Varuna, and Mitra,H.

p: Come as the laws of Heaven ordain, Varuna, Mitra, void of guile: Press near and drink the Soma juice.

p: Come, Mitra, Varuna, accept. Heroes, our offerings gift: Drink Soma, ye who strengthen Law.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVII. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: I WITH a holy heart that brings oblation will sing forth praise to meet your car, ye Princes, Which, Much-desired! hath wakened as your envoy. I call you hither as a son his parents.

p: Brightly hath Agni shone by us enkindled: the limits even of darkness were apparent. Eas ward is seen the Banner of the Morning, the Banner born to give Heaven's Daughter glory.

p: With hymns the deft priest is about you, Asvins, the eloquent priest attends you now, Nasatyas. Come by the paths that ye are wont to travel, on car that finds the light, laden with treasure..

p: When, suppliant for your help, Lovers of Sweetness! I seeking wealth call you to our libation, Hitherward let your vigorous horses bear you: drink ye with us the well-pressed Soma juices.

p: Bring forward, Asvins, Devas, to its fulfilment my never-wearied prayer that asks for riches. Vouchsafe us all high spirit in the combat, and with your powers, O Lords of Power, assist us.

p: Favour us in these prayers of ours, O Asvins. May we have genial vigour, ne’er to fail us. May we, strong in children and descendants, go, wealthy, to the banquet that awaits you.

p: Lovers of Sweetness, we have brought this treasure. to you as ’twere an envoy sent for friendship. Come unto us with spirits free from anger, in homes of men enjoying our oblation.

p: With one, the same, intention, ye swift movers, o’er the Seven Rivers hath your chariot travelled. Yoked by the Devas, your strong steeds never weary while speeding forward at the pole they bear you.

p: Exhaustless be your bounty to our princes who with their wealth incite the gift of riches, who further friendship with their noble natures, combining wealth in kine with wealth in herses.

p: Now hear, O Youthful Twain, mine invocation: come, Asvins, to the home where food aboundeth. Vouchsafe us wealth, do honour to our nobles. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXVIII. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: COME, radiant Asvins, with your noble horses: accept your servant's hymns, ye Wonder-Workers: Enjoy oblations which we bring to greet you.

p: The gladdening juices stand prepared before you: come quickly and partake of mine oblation. Pass by the calling of our foe and bear us.

p: Your chariot with a hundred aids, O Asvins, beareth you swift as thought across the regions, Speeding to us, O ye whose wealth is Surya.

p: What time this stone of yours, the Devas’ adorer, upraised, sounds forth for you as Soma-presser, Let the Sage bring you, Fair Ones, through oblations.

p: The nourishment ye have is, truly, wondrous: ye gave thereof a quickening store to Atri, who being dear to you, receives your favour.

p: That gift, which al. May gain, ye gave Cyavana, when he grew old, who offered you oblations, when ye bestowed on him enduring beauty.

p: What time his wicked friends abandoned Bhujyu, O Asvins, in the middle of the ocean, Your horse delivered him, your faithful servant.

p: Ye lent your aid to Vrka when exhausted, and listened when invoked to Sayu's calling. Ye made the cow pour forth her milk like water, and, Asvins, strengthened with your strength the barren.

p: With his fair hymns this singer, too, extols you, waking with glad thoughts at the break of morning. May the cow nourish him with milk to feed llim. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXIX. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: MAY your gold chariot, drawn by vigorous horses, come to us, blocking up the earth and heaven, Bright with its fellies while its way drops fatness, food-laden, rich in coursers, man's protector.

p: Let it approach, yoked by thewill, three-seated, extending far and wide o’er fivefold beings, Whereon ye visit Deva.adoring races, bending your course whither ye will, O Asvins.

p: Renowned, with noble horses, come ye hither: drink, Wondrous Pair, the cup that holds sweet juices. Your car whereon your Spouse is wont to travel marks with its track the farthest ends of heaven.

p: When night was turning to the grey of morning the Maiden, Surya's Daughter, chose your splendour. When with your power and might ye aid the pious he comes through heat to life by your assistance.

p: O Chariot-borne, this car of yours invested with rays of light comes harnessed to our dwelling. Herewith, O Asvins, while the dawn is breaking, to this  'our offering bring peace and blessing.

p: Like the wild cattle thirsty for the lightning. Heroes, come nigh this day to our libations. Men call on you with hymns in many places, but let not other worshippers detain you.

p: Bhujyu, abandoned in the midst of ocean, ye raised from out the water with your horses, Uninjured, winged, flagging not, undaunted, with deeds of wonder saving him, O Asvins.

p: Now hear, O Youthful Twain, mine invocation: come, Asvins, to the home where food aboundeth. Vouchsafe us wealth, do honour to our nobles. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXX. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: RICH in all blessings, Asvins come ye hither: this place on earth is called your own possessionlike a strong horse with a fair back it standeth, whereon, as in a lap, ye seat you firmly.

p: This most delightful eulogy awaits you in the man's house drink-offering hath been heated, Which bringeth you over the seas and rivers, yoking as’twere two well-matched shining horses.

p: Whatever dwellings ye possess, O Asvins, in fields of men or in the streams of heaven, Resting upon the summit of the mountain, or bringing food to him who gives oblation,

p: Delight yourselves, ye Devas, in plants and waters when Rsis give them and ye find they suit You. Enriching us with treasure.s in abundance ye have looked back to former generations.

p: Asvins, though ye have heard them oft aforetime, regard the many prayers which Rsis offer. Come to the man even as his heart desireth. May we enjoy your most delightful favour.

p: Come to  'the offering offered you, Nasatyas, with men, oblations, and prayer duly uttered. Come to Vasistha as his heart desireth, for unto you these holy hymns are chanted.

p: This is the thought, this is the song, O Asvins: accept this hymn of ours, ye Steers, with favour. May these our meditations addressed to you come nigh you. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXI. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: THE Night retireth from the Dawn her Sister; the Dark one yieldeth to the Red her pathway. Let us invoke you rich in steeds and cattle - by day and night keep far from us the arrow.

p: Bearing rich treasure. in your car, O Asvins, come to the mortal who presents oblation. Keep at a distance penury and sickness; Lovers of Sweetness, day and night preserve us.

p: May your strong horses, seeking bliss, bring hither your chariot at the earliest flush of morning. With coursers yoked by Law drive hither, Asvins, your car whose reins are light, laden with treasure..

p: The chariot, princes, that conveys you, moving at daylight, triple-seated, fraught with riches, Even with this come unto us, Nasatyas, that laden with all food i. May approach us.

p: Ye freed Cyavana from old age and weakness: ye brought the courser fleet of food to Pedu. Ye rescued Atri from distress and darkness, and loosed for Jahusa the bonds that bound him.

p: This is the thought, this is the song, O Asvins: accept this hymn of ours, ye Steers, with favour. May these our meditations addressed to you come nigh you. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXII. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: COME, O Nasatyas, on your car resplendent, rich in abundant wealth of kine and horses. As harnessed steeds, all our laudations follow you whose forms shine with most delightful beauty.

p: Come with the Devas associate, come ye hither to us, Nasatyas, with your car accordant. 'Twixt you and us there is ancestral friendship and common kin: remember and regard it.

p: Awakened are the songs that praise the Asvins, the kindred prayers and the Celestial Mornings. Inviting those we long for, Earth and Heaven, the singer calleth these Nasatyas hither.

p: What time the Dawns break forth in light, O Asvins, to you the poets offer their devotions. Deva.Savitar hath sent aloft his splendour, and fires sing praises with the kindled fuel.

p: Come from the west, come from the cast, Nasatyas, come, Asvins, from below and from above us. Bring wealth from all sides for the Fivefold People. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXIII. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: WE have o’erpassed the limit of this darkness while, worshipping the Devas, we sang their praises. The song invoketh both Immortal Asvins far-reaching, born of old, great WonderWorkers.

p: And, O Nasatyas, man's dear Monk is seated, who brings to offering and offers worship, be near and taste the pleasant juice, O Asvins: with food, I call you to  'the offerings.

p: We choosing you, have let our worship follow its course: ye Steers, accept this hymn with favour. Obeying you as your appointed servant, Vasistha singing hath with lauds aroused you.

p: And these Two Monks come nigh unto our people, united, demon-slayers, mighty-handed. The juices that exhilarate are mingled. Injure us not, but come with happy fortune.

p: Come from the west, come from the cast, Nasatyas, come, Asvins, from below and from above us. Bring wealth from all sides for the Fivefold People. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN I.XXIV. Asvins.
hymns.text:
p: THESE morning offers call you, Asvins, at the break of day. For help have I invoked you rich in power and might: for, house by house ye visit all.

p: O Heroes, ye bestow wonderful nourishment. send it to him whose songs are sweet Accordant, both of you, drive your car down to us, and drink the savoury Soma juice.

p: Approach ye and be near to us. drink, O ye Asvins, of the meath. Draw forth the milk, ye Mighty, rich in genuine wealth: injure us not, and come to us.

p: The horses that convey you in their rapid flight down to the worshipper's abode, with these your speedy coursers. Heroes, Asvins, come, ye Devas, come well-inclined to us.

p: Yea, verily, our princes seek the Asvins in pursuit of food. These shall give lasting glory to our liberal lords, and, both Nasatyas, shelter us.

p: Those who have led the way, like cars, offending none, those who are guardians of the men- Also through their own might the heroes have grown strong, and dwell in safe and happy homes.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXV. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: BORN in the heavens the Dawn hath flushed, and showing her majesty is come as Law ordaineth. She hath uncovered fiends and hateful darkness; best of Angirases, hath waked the pathways.

p: Rouse us this day to high and happy fortune: to great felicity, O Dawn, promote us. Vouchsafe us manifold and splendid riches, famed among mortals, man-befriending Deva!

p: See, lovely Morning's everlasting splendours, bright with their varied colours, have approached us. Filling the region of mid-air, producing the rites of holy worship, they have mounted.

p: She yokes her chariot far away, and swiftly visits the lands where the Five Tribes are settled, Looking upon the works and ways of mortals, Daughter of Heaven, the world's Imperial Lady.

p: She who is rich in spoil, the Spouse of Surya, wondrously opulent, rules all wealth and treasure.s. Consumer of our youth, the seers extol her: lauded by monks rich Dawn shines out refulgent.

p: Apparent are the steeds of varied colour, the red steeds carrying resplendent Morning. On her all-lovely car she comes, the Fair One, and brings rich treasure. for her faithful servant.

p: True with the True and Mighty with the Mighty, with Devas a Deva, Holy with the Holy, she brake strong fences down and gave the cattle: the kine were lowing as they greeted Morning.

p: O Dawn, now give us wealth in kine and heroes, and horses, fraught with manifold enjoyment. Protect our sacred grass from man's reproaches. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVI. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: SAVITAR Deva.of all men hath sent upward his light, designed for all mankind, immortal. Through the Devas’ power that Eye was first created. Dawn hath made all the universe apparent.

p: I see the paths which Devas are wont to travel, innocuous paths made ready by the Vasus. Eas ward the flag of Dawn hath been uplifted; she hath come hither o’er the tops of houses.

p: Great is, in truth, the number of the Mornings which were aforetime at the Sun's uprising. Since thou, O Dawn, hast been beheld repairing as to thy love, as one no more to leave him.

p: They were the Devas’ companions at the banquet, the ancient sages true to Law Eternal. The Fathers found the light that lay in darkness, and with effectual words begat the Morning.

p: Meeting together in the same enclosure, they strive not, ofone mind, one with another. They never break the Devas’ eternal statutes, and injure none, in rivalry with Vasus.

p: Extolling thee, Blest Deva, the Vasisthas, awake at early mom, with lauds implore thee. Leader of kine and Queen of all that strengthens, shine, come as first to us, O high-born Morning.

p: She bringeth bounty and sweet charm of voices. The flushing Dawn is sung by the Vasisthas, giving us riches famed to distant places. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVIT. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: SHE hath shone brightly like a youthful woman, stirring to motion every living creature.. Agni hath come to feed on mortal? fuel. She hath made light and chased away the darkness.

p: Turned to this All, far-spreading, she hath risen and shone in brightness with white robes about her. She hath beamed forth lovely with golden colours, Mother of kine, Guide of the days she bringeth.

p: Bearing the Devas’ own Eye, auspicious Lady, leading her Courser white and fair to look on, Distinguished by her bean-is Dawn shines apparent, come forth to all the world with wondrous treasure..

p: Draw nigh with wealth and dawn away the foeman: prepare for us wide pasture free from danger. Drive away those who hate us, bring us riches: pour bounty, opulent Lady, on the singer.

p: Send thy most excellent beams to shine and light us, giving us lengthened days, O Dawn, O Deva, Granting us food, thou who hast all things precious, and bounty rich in chariots, kine, and horses.

p: O Usas, nobly-born, Daughter of Heaven, whom the Vasisthas with their hymns make mighty, bestow thou on us vast and glorious riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXVIII. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: WE have beheld her earliest lights approaching: her many glories part, on high, asunder. On car sublime, refulgent, wending hither, O Usas, bring the Wealth that makes us happy.

p: The fire well-kindIed sings aloud to greet her, and with their hymns the monks are chaming welcome. Usas approaches in her splendour, driving all evil darkness far away, the Deva.

p: Apparent eas ward are those lights of Morning, sending out lustre, as they rise, around them. She hath brought forth Sun, offering, and Agni, and far away hath fled detested darkness.

p: Rich Daughter of the Sky, we all behold her, yea, all men look on Dawn as she is breaking. fler car that moves self-harnessed hath she mounted, the car drawn onward by her well-yoked horses.

p: Inspired with loving thoughts this day to greet thee, we and our wealthy nobles have awakened. Show yourselves fruitful, Dawns, as ye are rising. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXIX. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: ROUSING the lands where men's Five Tribes are settled, Dawn hath disclosed the pathways of the people. She hath sent out her sheen with beauteous oxen. The Sun with light hath opened earth and heaven.

p: They paint their bright rays on the sky's far limits. the Dawns come on like tribes arrayed for battle. Thy cattle, closely shutting up the darkness, as Savitar spreads his arms, give forth their lustre.

p: Wealthy, most like to Indra, Dawn hath risen, and brought forth lauds that shall promote our welfare. Daughter of Heaven, a Deva, she distributes, best of Angirases, treasure.s to the pious.

p: Bestow on us, O Dawn, that ample bounty which thou didst send to those who sang thy praises; Thou whom with bellowings of a bull they quickened: thou didst unbar the firm-set mountain's portals.

p: Impelling every Deva.to grant his bounty sending to us the charm of pleasant voices, vouchsafe us thoughts, for profit, as thou breakest. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXX. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: THE monks, Vasisthas, are the first awakened to welcome Usas with their songs and praises, who makes surrounding regions part asunder,and shows apparent all existing creatures.

p: Giving fresh life when she hath hid the darkness, this Dawn hath wakened there with new-born lustre. Youthful and unrestrained she cometh forward: she hath turned thoughts to Sun and fire and worship.

p: May blessed Mornings shine on us forever, with wealth of kine, of horses, and of heroes, Streaming with all abundance, pouring fatness. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXI. Dawn.
hymns.text:
p: ADVANCING, sending forth her rays, the Daughter of the Sky is seen. Uncovering, that we may see, the mighty gloom, the friendly Lady makes the light.

p: The Sun ascending, the refulgent Star, pours down his beams together with the Dawn. O Dawn, at thine arising, and the Sun's. May we attain the share allotted us.

p: Promptly we woke to welcome thee, O Usas, Daughter of the Sky, thee, Bounteous One, who bringest all we long to have, and to the offerer health and wealth.

p: Thou, dawning, workest fain to light the great world, yea, heaven, Deva! that he may be seen. We yearn to be thine own, Dealer of Wealth. May we be to this Mother like her sons.

p: Bring us that wondrous bounty, Dawn, that shall be famed most far away. What, Child of Heaven, thou hast of nourishment for man, bestow thou on us to enjoy.

p: Give to our princes opulence and immortal fame, and strength in herds of kine to us. May she who prompts the wealthy, Lady of sweet strains. May Usas dawn our foes away.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIT. Indra-Varuna
hymns.text:
p: GRANT us your strong protection, Varuna, and Mitra, our people, and our family, for offering. May we subdue in fight our evil-hearted foes, him who attacks the man steadfast in lengthened rites.

p: O Indra-Varuna, mighty and very rich One of you is called Monarch and One Autocrat. All Devas in the most lofty region of the air have, O ye Steers, combined all power and might in you.

p: Ye with your strength have pierced the fountains of the floods: the Sun have ye brought forward as the Lord in heaven. Cheered by this magic draught ye, indra-Varuna, made the dry places stream, made songs of praise flow forth.

p: In battels and in frays we ministering monks, kneeling upon our knees for furtherance of our weal, invoke you, only you, the Lords of twofold wealth, you prompt to hear, we bards, O Indra-Varuna.

p: O Indra-Varuna, as ye created all these creatures of the world by your surpassing might, in peace and quiet Mitra waits on Varuna, the Other, awful, with the Maruis seeks renown.

p: That Varuna's high wort. May shine preeminent, these Twain have measured each his proper power and might. The One subdueth the destructive enemy; the Other with a few furthereth many a man.

p: No trouble, no misfortune, indra-Varuna, no woe from any side assails the mortal man Whose offering, O Devas, ye visit and enjoy: ne’er doth the crafty guile of mortal injure him.

p: With your divine protection. Heroes, come to us: mine invncation hear, if ye be pleased therewith. Bestow ye upon us, O Indra-Varuna, your friendship and your kinship and your favouring grace.

p: In battle after battle, indra-Varuna, be ye our Champions, ye who are the peoples' strength, when both opposing bands invoke you for the fight, and men that the, may gain offspring and progeny.

p: May Indra, Varuna, Mitra, and Aryaman vouchsafe us glory and great shelter spreading far. We think of the beneficent light of Aditi, and Savitar's song of praise, the Deva who strengthens Law.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIII. Indra-Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: LOOKING to you and your alliance, O ye Men, armed with broad axes they went forward, fain for spoil. Ye smote and slew his Dasa and his Aryan enemies, and helped Sudas with favour, indra-Varuna.

p: Where heroes come together with their banners raised, in the encounter where is naught for us to love, Where all things that behold the light are terrified, there did ye comfort us, O Indra-Varuna.

p: The boundaries of earth were seen all dark with dust: O Indra-Varuna, the shout went up to heaven. The enmities of the people compassed me about. Ye heard my calling and ye came to me with help.

p: With your resistless weapons, indra-Varuna, ye conquered Bheda and ye gave Sudas your aid. Ye heard the prayers of these amid the cries of war: effectual was the service of the Trtsus' priest.

p: O Indra-Varuna, the wickedness of foes and mine assailants' hatred sorely trouble me. Ye Twain are Lords of riches both of earth and heaven: so grant to us your aid on the decisive day.

p: The men of both the hosts invoked you in the fight, indra and Varuna, that they might win the wealth, what time ye helped Sudas, with all the Trtsu folk, when the Ten Kings had pressed him down in their attack.

p: Ten Kings who worshipped not, O Indra-Varuna, confederate, in war prevailed not o’er Sudas. True was the boast of heroes sitting at the feast: so at their invocations Devas were on their side.

p: O Indra-Varuna, ye gave Sudas your aid when the Ten Kings in battle compassed him about, there where the white-robed Trtsus with their braided hair, skilled in song worshipped you with homage and with hymn.

p: One of you Twain destroys the Vrtras in the fight, the Other evermore maintains his holy Laws. We call on you, ye Mighty, with our hymns of praise. Vouchsafe us your protection, indra-Varuna.

p: May Indra, Varuna, Mitra, and Aryaman vouchsafe us glory and great shelter spreading far. We think of the beneficent light of Aditi, and Savitar's song of praise, the Deva who strengthens Law.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIV. Indra-Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: KINGS, indra-Varuna, I would turn you hither to this  'our offering with gifts and homage. Held in both arms the ladle, dropping fatness, goes of itself to you whose forms are varied.

p: Dyaus quickens and promotes your high dominion who bind with bonds not wrought of rope or cordage. Far from us still be Varuna's displeasur. May Indra give us spacious room to dwell in.

p: Make ye  'our offering fair amid the assemblies: make ye our meditations approved among our princes. May Deva.sent riches come for our possession: further ye us with your delightful assists.

p: O Indra-Varuna, vouchsafe us riches with store of treasure., food, and every blessing; For the Aditya, banisher of falsehood, the Hero, dealeth wealth in boundless plenty.

p: May this my song reach Varuna and Indra, and, strongly urging, win me sons and offspring. To the Devas’ banque. May we go with riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXV. Indra-Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: FOR you I deck a harmless hymn, presenting the Soma juice to Varuna and Indra- A hymn that shines like heavenly Dawn with fatness. May they be near us on the march and guard us.

p: Here where the arrows fall amid the banners both hosts invoke the Devas in emulation. O Indra-Varuna, smite back those-our foemen,yea, smite them withyour shaft to every quarter.

p: Self-lucid in their seats, e’en heavenly Waters endowed with Deva.ead Varuna and Indra. One of these holds the folk distinct and sundered, the Other smites and subdues resistless foemen.

p: Wise be the Sage and skilled in Law Eternal, who with his sacred gifts and oration. Brings you to aid us with your might, Adityas: let him have offerings to promote his welfare.

p: May this my song reach Varuna and Indra, and, strongly urging, win me sons and offspring. To the Devas’ banque. May we go with riches. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVI. Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: WISE, verily, are creatures through his greatness who stayed ever, spacious heaven and earth asunder. Who urged the high and mighty sky to motion, the Star of old, and spread the earth before him.

p: With mine own heart I commune on the question how Varuna and . May be united. What gift of mine will he accept unangered? Whe. May I calmly look and find him gracious?

p: Fain to know this is my sin I question others: I seek the wise, O Varuna, and ask them. This one same answer even the sages gave me, "Surely this Varuna is angry with thee."

p: What, Varuna, hath been my chief transgression, that thou wouldst subdue the friend who sings thy praises? Tell me, Unconquerable Lord, and quickly sinless will I approach thee with mine homage.

p: Free us from sins committed by our fathers, from those wherein we have ourselves offended. O King, loose, like a thief who feeds the cattle, as from the cord a calf, set free Vasistha.

p: Not our own will betrayed us, but seduction, thoughtlessness, Varuna wine, dice, or anger. The old is near to lead astray the younger: even sleep removeth not all evil-doing.

p: Slavelik. May I do service to the Bounteous, serve, free from sin, the Deva.inclined to anger. This gentle Lord gives wisdom to the simple: the wiser Deva.leads on the wise to riches.

p: O Lord, O Varuna. May this laudation come close to thee and lie within thy spirit. May it be well with us in rest and labour. Preserve us ever-more, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVII. Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: VARUNA cut a pathway out for Surya, and led the watery floods of rivers onward. The Mares, as in a race, speed on in order. He made great channels for the days to follow.

p: The wind, thy breath, hath sounded through the region like a wild beast that seeks his food in pastures. Within these two, exalted Earth and Heaven, O Varuna, are all the forms thou lovest.

p: Varuna's spies, sent forth upon their errand, survey the two world-halves well formed and fashioned. Wise are they, holy, skilled in offers, the furtherers of the praise-songs of the prudent.

p: To me who understand hath Varuna spoken, the names borne by the Cow are three times seven. The sapient Deva, knowing the place's secret, shall speak as ’twere to teach the race that cometh.

p: On him three heavens rest and are supported, and the three earths are there in sixfold order. The wise King Varuna hath made in heaven that Golden Swing to cover it with glory.

p: Like Varuna from heaven he sinks in Sindhu, like a white-shining spark, a strong wild creature.. Ruling in depths and meting out the region, great saving power hath he, this world's Controller.

p: Before this Varun. May we be sinless him who shows mercy even to the sinner- While we are keeping Aditi's ordinances. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXVIII. Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: PRESENT to Varuna thine hymn, Vasistha, bright, most delightful to the Bounteous Giver, who bringeth on to us the Bull, the lofty, the Holy, laden with a thousand treasure.s.

p: And now, as I am come before his presence, I take the face of Varuna for Agni's. So might he bring-Lord also of the darkness-the light in heaven that . May see its beauty!

p: When Varuna and I embark together and urge our boat into the midst of ocean, We, when we ride o’er ridges of the waters, will swing within that swing and there be happy.

p: Varuna placed Vasistha in the vessel, and deftly with his niight made him a Rsi. When days shone bright the Sage made him a singer, while the heavens broadened and the Dawns were lengthened.

p: What hath become of those our ancient friendships, when without enmity we walked together? I, Varuna, thou glorious Lord, have entered thy lofty home, thine house with thousand portals.

p: If he, thy true ally, hath sinned against thee, still, Varuna, he is the friend thou lovedst. Let us not, Living One, as sinners I know thee: give shelter, as a Sage, to him who lauds thee.

p: While we abide in these fixed habitations, and from the lap of Aditi win favour, may Varuna untie the bond that binds us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN LXXXIX Varuna.
hymns.text:
p: LET me not yet, King Varuna, enter into the house of clay: Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

p: When, Thunderer! I move along tremulous like a wind-blown skin, have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

p: O Bright and Powerful Deva, through want of strength I erred and went astray Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

p: Thirst found thy worshipper though he stood in the midst of water-fijods: Have mercy, spare me, Mighty Lord.

p: O Varuna, whatever the offenc. May be which we as men commit against the heavenly host, when through our want of thought we violate thy laws, punish us not, O Deva, for that iniquity.

hymns.title: HYMN XC. Vayu.
hymns.text:
p: To you pure juice, rich in meath, are offered by priest: through longing for the Pair of Heroes. Drive, Vayu, bring thine harnessed horses hither: drink the pressed Soma till it make thee joyful.

p: Whoso to thee, the Mighty, brings oblation, pure Soma unto thee, pure-drinking Vayu, that man thou makest famous among mortals: to him strong sons are born in quick succession.

p: The Deva whom both these worlds brought forth for riches, whom heavenly Dhisana for our wealth appointeth, His team of harnessed horses waits on Vayu, and, foremost, on the radiant Treasure-bearer.

p: The spotless Dawns with fair bright days have broken; they found the spacious light when they were shining. Eagerly they disclosed the stall of cattle: floods streamed for them as in the days aforetime.

p: These with their truthful spirit, shining brightly, move on provided with their natural insight. Viands attend the car that beareth Heroes, your car, ye Sovran Pair, indra and Vayu.

p: May these who give us heavenly light, these rulers, with gifts of kine and horses, gold and treasure.s. These princes, through full life, indra and Vayu! o’ercome in battle with their steeds and heroes.

p: Like coursers seeking fame will we Vasisthas, O Indra and Vayu, with our fair laudations. Exerting all our power call you to aid us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCI. Vayu.
hymns.text:
p: WERE not in sooth, the Devas aforetime blameless, whose pleasure was increased by adoration? For Vayu and for man in his affliction they caused the Morning to arise with Surya.

p: Guardians infallible, eager as envoys' preserve us safe through many months and autumns. Addressed to you, our fair praise, indra and Vayu, implores your favour and renewed well-being.

p: Wise, bright, arranger of his teams, he. seeketh men with rich food whose treasure.s are abundant. They have arranged them of one mind with Vayu: the men have wrought all noble operations.

p: So far as native power and strength permit you, so far as men behold whose eyes have vision, O ye pure-drinkers, drink with us pure Soma: sit on this sacred grass, indra and Vayu.

p: Driving down teams that bear the lovely Heroes, hitherward, indra and Vayu, come together. To you this prime of savoury juice is offered: here loose your horses and be friendly-minded.

p: Your hundred and your thousand teams, O Indra and Vayu, all-munificent, which attend you, with these most gracious-minded come ye hither, and drink, O Heroes of the meath we offer.

p: Like coursers seeking fame will we Vasisthas, O Indra and Vayu, with our fair laudations, Exerting all our powe-, call you to aid us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCII. Vayu
hymns.text:
p: O VAYU, drinker of the pure, be near us: a thousand teams are thine, Allbounteous Giver. To thee the rapture-bringing juice is offered, whose first draught, Deva, thou takest as thy portion.

p: Prompt at the holy rites forth came the presser with Soma-draughts for Indra and for Vayu, when ministering monks with strong devotion bring to you Twain the first taste of the Soma.

p: The teams wherewith thou seekest him who offers, within his home, O Viyu, to direct him, therewith send wealth: to us with full enjoyment, a hero son and gifts of kine and horses.

p: Near to the Devas and making Indra joyful, devout and ofFering precious gifts to Vayu, Allied with princes, smiting down the hostile. May we with heroes conquer foes in battle.

p: With thy yoked teams in hundreds and in thousands come to  'our offering and solemn worship. Come, Vayu, make thee glad at this libation. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIII. Indra and Agni.
hymns.text:
p: SLAYERS of enemies, indra and Agni, accept this day our new-born pure laudation. Again, again I call you prompt to listen, best to give quickly strength to him who craves it.

p: For ye were strong to gain, exceeding mighty, growing together, waxing in your vigour. Lords of the pasture filled with ample riches, bestow upon us strength both fresh and lasting.

p: Yea when the strong have entered our assembly, and singers seeking with their hymns your favour, they are like steeds who come into the race-course, those men who call aloud on Indra and Agni.

p: The singer, seeking with his hymns your favour, begs splendid riches of their first possessor. Further us with new bounties, indra and Agni, armed with strong thunder, slayers of the foeman.

p: When two great hosts, arrayed against each other, meet clothed with brightness, in the fierce encounter Stand ye beside the godly, smite the godless; and still assist the men who press the Soma.

p: To this our Soma-pressing, indra and Agni, come ye prepared to show your loving-kindness, for not at any time have ye despised us. May I draw you with all strengthenings hither.

p: So Agni, kindled mid this adoration, invite thou Mitra, Varuna, and Indra. Forgive whatever sin we have committe. May Aryaman and Aditi remove it.

p: While we accelerate these  'our offerings. May we win strength from both of you, O Agni: Ne’e. May the Maruts, indra, Visnu slight us. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIV. Indra and Agni.
hymns.text:
p: As rain from out the cloud, for you, indra and Agni, from my soul This noblest praise hath been produced.

p: Do ye, O Indra and Agni, hear the singer's call: accept his songs. Ye Rulers, grant his heart's desire.

p: Give us not up to poverty, ye Heroes, indra and Agni, nor To slander and reproach of men.

p: To Indra and to Agni we bring reverence, high and holy hymn, and, craving help, softwords with prayer.

p: For all these holy singers here implore these Twain to assist them, and monks that the, may win them strength.

p: Eager to laudyou, we with songs invoke you, bearing sacred food, fain for success in offering.

p: Indra and Agni, come to us with favour, ye who conquer men: Let not the wicked master us.

p: At no time let the injurious blow of hostile mortal fall on us: O Indra and Agni, shelter us.

p: Whatever wealth we crave of you, in gold, in cattle, or in steeds, that, indra and Agni, let us gain;

p: When heroes prompt in worship call Indra and Agni, Lords of steeds, beside the Soma juice effused.

p: Call hither with the song and lauds those who best subdue the foemen, those Who take delight in hymns of praise.

p: Slay ye the wicked man whose thought is evil of the demon kind. Slay him who stays the waters, subdue the Serpent with your deadly dart.

hymns.title: HYMN XCV. Sarasvati.
hymns.text:
p: THIS stream Sarasvati with fostering current comes forth, our sure defence, our fort of iron. As on a car, the flood flows on, surpassing in majesty and might all other waters.

p: Pure in her course from mountains to the ocean, alone of streams Sarasvati hath listened. Thinking of wealth and the great world of creatures, she poured for Nahusa her milk and fatness.

p: Friendly to man he grew among the women, a strong young Steer amid the Holy Ladies. He gives the fleet steed to our wealthy princes, and decks their bodies for success in battle.

p: May this Sarasvati be pleased and listen at this  'our offering, auspicious Lady, when we with reverence, on our knees, implore her close-knit to wealth, most kind to those she loveth.

p: These offerings have ye made with adoration: say this, Sarasvati, and accept our praises; And, placing us under thy dear protection. May we approach thee, as a tree, for shelter.

p: For thee, O Blest Sarasvati, Vasistha hath here unbarred the doors d sacred Order. Wax, Bright One, and give strength to him who lauds thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVI. Sarasvati.
hymns.text:
p: I SING a lofty song, for she is mightiest, most divine of Streams. Sarasvati will I exalt with hymns and lauds, and, O Vasistha. Heaven and Earth.

p: When in the fulness of their strength the Purus dwell, beauteous One, on thy two grassy banks, Favour us thou who hast the Maruts for thy friends: stir up the bounty of our chiefs.

p: May Sarasvati auspicious send good luck; she, rich in spoil, is never niggardly in thought, when praised in jamadagni's way and lauded as Vasistha lauds.

p: We call upon Sarasvan, as unmarried men who long for wives, as liberal men who yearn for sons.

p: Be thou our kind protector, O Sarasvan, with those waves of thine Laden with sweets and dropping oil.

p: May we enjoy Sarasvan's breast, all-beautiful, that swells with streams, may we gain food and progeny.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVIL Narasamsa.
hymns.text:
p: WHERE Heaven and Earth combine in men's assembly, and ttose who love the Devas delight in worship, Where the libations are effused for Indra, may he come first to drink and make him stronger.

p: We crave the heavenly grace of Devas to guard us-s. May Narasamsa, O friends, exalt us- That he, the Bounteous Deva. May find us sintess, who giveth from a distance like a father.

p: That Narasamsa, most High and Gracious, I glorify with offerings and with homage. May the great song of praise divine, reach Indra who is the King of prayer the Devas’ creation.

p: May that Narasamsa who brings all blessings, most dearly loved, be seated by our altar. Heroes and wealth we crave. May he bestow them, and bear us safe beyond the men who vex us.

p: To us these Deathless Ones, erst born, have granted this laud of ours which gives the Immortal pleasure. Let us invoke Narasamsa, the foeless, the clear-voiced Deva, the Holy One of households

p: Him, this Narasamsa, his red-hued horses, drawing together, full of strength, bring hither. Robed in red colour like the cloud, they carry the Lord of Might whose friendship gives a dwelling.

p: For he is pure, with hundred wings, refulgent, with sword of gold, impetuous, winning sunlight. Sublime Narasamsa, easy of access granteth his friends most bountiful refreshment.

p: Both Heaven and Earth, divine, the Deity's Parents, have made Narasamsa increase in grandeur. Glorify him, O friends, who merits glory. May he give prayer fair way and easy passage.

p: This, Narasamsa, is your laudation prayer hath been made to thunderwielding Indra. Favour our songs, wake up our thought and spirit: destroy the godless and our foemen's malice.

p: Ye Twain are Lords of wealth in earth and heaven O Narasamsa, and thou, O Indra. Mean though he be, give wealth to him who lauds you. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCVIII. Indra.
hymns.text:
p: PRIESTS, offer to the Lord of all the people the milked-out stalk of Soma, radiant-coloured. No wild-bull knows his drinking-place like Indra who ever seeks him who hath pressed the Soma,

p: Thou dost desire to drink, each day that passes, the pleasant food which thou hast had aforetime, O Indra, gratified in heart and spirit, drink eagerly the Soma set before thee.

p: Thou, newly-born, for strength didst drink the Soma; the Mother told thee of thy future greatness. O Indra, thou hast filled mid-air's wide region, and given the Devas by battle room and freedom.

p: When thou hast urged the arrocrant to combat, proud in their strength of arm, we will subdue them. Or, indra, when thou fightest girt by heroes, we in the glorious fray with thee will conquer.

p: I will declare the earliest deeds of Indra, and recent acts which Maghavan hath accomplished. When he had conquered godless wiles and magic, Soma became his own entire possession.

p: Thine is this world of flocks and herds around thee, which with the eye of Surya thou beholdest. Thou, indra, art alone the Lord of cattle. May we enjoy the treasure. which thou givest.

p: Ye Twain are Lords of wealth in earth and heaven O Narasamsa, and thou, O Indra. Mean though he be, give wealth to him who lauds you. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN XCIX. Visnu.
hymns.text:
p: MEN come not nigh thy majesty who growest beyond all bound and measure with thy body. Both thy two regions of the earth, O Visnu, we know: thou Deva, knowest the highest also.

p: None who is born or being born, Deva.Visnu, hath reached the utmost limit of thy grandeur. The vast high vault of heaven hast thou supported, and fixed earth's eastern pinnacle securely.

p: Rich in sweet food be ye, and rich in milch-kine, with fertile pastures, fain to do men service. Both these worlds, Visnu, hast thou stayed asunder, and firmly fixed the earth with pegs around it.

p: Ye have made spacious room for sacrificing by generating Surya, Dawn, and Agni. O Heroes, ye have conquered in your battles even the bull-jawed Dasa's wiles and magic.

p: Ye have conquered Indra, and thou Visnu, Sambara's nine-and-ninety fenced castles. Ye Twain smote down a hundred times a thousand resistless heroes of the royal Varcin.

p: This is the lofty hymn of praise, exalting the Lords of Mighty Stride, the strong and lofty. I laud you in the solemn synods, Visnu: pour ye food on us in our camps, O Indra.

p: O Visnu, unto thee my lips cry Vasat! Let this mine offering, Sipivista, please thee. May these my songs of eulogy exalt thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN C. Visnu.
hymns.text:
p: NE’ER doth the man repent, who, seeking profit, bringeth his gift to the far-striding Visnu. He who adoreth him with all his spirit winneth himself so great a benefactor.

p: Thou, Visnu, constant in thy courses, gavest good-will to all men, and a hymn that lasteth, that thou mightst move us to abundant comfort of very splendid wealth with store of horses.

p: Three times strode forth this Deva in all his grandeur over this earth bright with a hundred splendours. Foremost be Visnu, stronger than the strongest: for glorious is his name who lives forever.

p: Over this earth with mighty step strode Visnu, ready to give it for a home to Manu. In him the humble people trust for safety: he, nobly born, hath made them spacious dwellings.

p: To-day I laud this name, O gipivista, I, skilled in rules, the name of thee the Noble. Yea, I the poor and weak praise thee the Mighty who dwellest in the realm beyond this region.

p: What was there to be blamed in thee, O Visnu, when thou declaredst, I am Sipivista? Hide not this form from us, nor keep it secret, since thou didst wear another shape in battle.

p: O Visnu, unto thee my lips cry Vasat! Let this mine offering, Sipivista, please thee. May these my songs of eulogy exalt thee. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN CI. Parjanya.
hymns.text:
p: SPEAK forth three words, the words which light precedeth, which milk this udder that produceth nectar. Quickly made manifest, the Bull hath bellowed, engendering the germ of plants, the Infant.

p: Giver of growth to plants, the Deva who ruleth over the waters and all moving creatures, vouchsafe us triple shelter for our refuge, and threefold light to assist and befriend us.

p: Now he is sterile, now begetteth offspring, even as he willeth doth he change his figure. The Father's genial flow bedews the Mother; therewith the Sire, therewith the son is nourished.

p: In him all living creatures have their being, and the three heavens with triply-flowing waters. Three reservoirs that sprinkle down their treasure. shed their sweet streams around him with a murmur.

p: May this my song to Sovran Lord Parjanya come near unto his heart and give him pleasure. May we obtain the showers that bring enjoyment, and Deva protected plants with goodly fruitage.

p: He is the Bull of all, and their impregner: he holds the life of all things fixed and moving. May this rite save me till my hundredth autumn. Preserve us evermore, ye Devas, with blessings.

hymns.title: HYMN CII Parjanya.
hymns.text:
p: SING forth and laud Parjanya, son of Heaven, who sends the gift of rain May he provide our pasturage.

p: Parjanya is the Deva who forms in kine, in mares, in plants of earth, and womankind, the germ of life.

p: Offer and pour into his mouth oblation rich in savoury juice: May he forever give us food.

hymns.title: HYMN CIII. Frogs.
hymns.text:
p: THEY who lay quiet for a year, the Brahmans who fulfil their vows, the Frogs have lifted up their voice, the voice Parjanya hath inspired.

p: What time on these, as on a dry skin lying in the pool's bed, the floods of heaven descended, the music of the Frogs comes forth in concert like the cows lowing with their calves beside them.

p: When at the coming of the Rains the water has poured upon them as they yearned and thirsted, One seeks another as he talks and greets him with cries of pleasure as a son his father.

p: Each of these twain receives the other kindly, while they are revelling in the flow of waters, when the Frog moistened by the rain springs forward, and Green and Spotty both combine their voices.

p: When one of these repeats the other's language, as he who learns the lesson of the teacher, Your every limb seems to be growing larger as ye converse with eloquence on the waters.

p: Onc is Cow-bellow and Goat-bleat the other, one Frog is Green and one of them is Spotty. They bear one common name, and yet they vary, and, talking, modulate the voice diversely.

p: As Brahmans, sitting round the brimful vessel, talk at the Soma-rite of Atiratra, So, Frogs, ye gather round the pool to honour this day of all the year, the first of Rain-time.

p: These Brahmans with the Soma juice, performing their year-long rite, have lifted up their voices; And these Adhvaryus, sweating with their kettles, come forth and show themselves, and none are hidden.

p: They keep the twelve month's Deva.appointed order, and never do the men neglect the season. Soon as the Rain-time in the year returneth, these who were heated kettles gain their freedom.

p: Cow-bellow and Goat-bleat have granted riches, and Green and Spotty have vouchsafed us treasure.. The Frogs who give us cows in hundreds lengthen our lives in this most fertilizing season.

hymns.title: HYMN CIV. Indra and Soma.
hymns.text:
p: INDRA and Soma, burn, destroy the demon foe, send downward, O ye Bulls, those who add gloom to gloom. Annihilate the fools, subdue them and burn them up: chase them away from us, pierce the voracious ones.

p: Indra and Soma, let sin round the wicked boil like as a caldron set amid the flames of fire. Against the foe of prayer, devourer of raw flesh, the vile fiend fierce of eye, keep ye perpetual hate.

p: Indra and Soma, plunge the wicked in the depth, yea, cast them into darkness that hath no support, So that not one of the, may ever thence return: s. May your wrathful might prevail and conquer them.

p: Indra and Soma, hurl your deadly crushing bolt down on the wicked fiend from heaven and from the earth. Yea, forge out of the mountains your celestial dart wherewith ye burn to death the waxing demon race.

p: Indra and Soma, cast ye downward out of heaven your deadly darts of stone burning with fiery flame, Eternal, scorching darts; plunge the voracious ones within the depth, and let them sink without a sound.

p: Indra and Soma, let this hymn control you both, even as the girth encompasses two vigorous steeds- The song of praise which I with wisdom offer you: do ye, as Lords of men, animate these my meditations.

p: In your impetuous manner think ye both thereon: destroy these evil beings, subdue the treacherous fiends. Indra and Soma, let the wicked have no bliss who evermore assails us with malignity.

p: Whoso accuses me with words of falsehood when I pursue my way with guileless spirit, may he, the speaker of untruth, be, indra, like water which the hollowed hand compresses.

p: Those who destroy, as is their wont, the simple, and with their evil natures barm the righteous, may Soma give them over to the serpent, or to the lap of Nirrti consign them.

p: The fiend, O Agni, who designs to injure the essence of our food, kine, steeds, or bodies, may he, the adversary, thief, and robber, sink to destruction, both himself and offipring.

p: May he be swept away, himself and children. May all the three earths press him down beneath them. May his fair glory, O ye Devas, be blighted, who in the day or night would fain destroy us.

p: The prudent finds it easy to distinguish the true and false: their words oppose each other. Of these two that which is the true and honest, Soma protects, and brings the false to nothing.

p: Never doth Soma aid and guide the wicked or him who falsely claims the Warrior's title. He subdues the fiend and him who speaks untruly: both lie entangled in the noose of Indra.

p: As if I worshipped deities of falsehood, or thought vain thoughts about the Devas, O Agni. Why art thou angry with us, Jatavedas? Destruction fall on those who lie against thee!

p: May I die this day if I have harassed any man's life or if I be a demon. Yea. May he lose all his ten sons together who with false tongue hath called me Yatudhana.

p: May Indra subdue him with a mighty weapon, and let the vilest of all creatures perish, the fiend who says that he is pure, who calls me a demon though devoid of demon nature.

p: She too who wanders like an owl at night-time, hiding her body in her guile and malice, may she fall downward into endless caverns. May press-stones with loud ring destroy the demons.

p: Spread out, ye Maruts, search among the people: seize ye and grind the Raksasas to pieces, who fly abroad, transformed to birds, at night-time, or sully and pollute our holy worship.

p: Hurl down from heaven thy bolt of stone, O Indra: sharpen it, Maghavan, made keen by Soma. Forward, behind, and from above and under, smite down the demons with thy rocky weapon.

p: They fly, the demon dogs, and, bent on mischief, fain would they harm indomitable Indra. Sakra makes sharp his weapon for the wicked: now, let him cast his bolt at fiendish wizards.

p: Indra hath ever been the fiends’ destroyer who spoil oblations of the Devas’ invokers: Yea, Sakra, like an axe that splits the timber, attacks and smashes them like earthen vessels.

p: Destroy the fiend shaped like an owl or owlet, destroy him in the form of dog or cuckoo. Destroy him shaped as eagle or as vulture as with a stone, O Indra, crush the demon.

p: Let not the fiend of witchcraft-workers reach us. May Dawn drive off the couples of Kimidins. Earth keep us safe from earthly woe and trouble: from grief that comes from heaven mid-air preserve us.

p: Slay the male demon, indra! subdue the female, joying and triumphing in arts of magic. Let the fools' gods with bent necks fall and perish, and see no more the Sun when he arises.

p: Look each one hither, look around Indra and Soma, watch ye well.
